DEBATE.TITLE: INDUSTRY, TECHNOLOGY AND REGIONAL DEVELOPMENT LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1993

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 16 December 1993, on motion by Senator Sherry:
That this bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Industry, Technology and Regional Development Legislation Amendment Bill is an omnibus bill which provides for a range of mainly administrative amendments to be made to the Patents Act 1990, the Trade Marks Act 1955 and the Designs Act 1906. The Australian Democrats support most of these provisions in the bill, and we support the bill as a whole. However, there are some matters of concern, mainly related to the delegation of powers and to the possible extension of powers of the registrar by regulation, which I will address later in greater detail.

PARA.TAB: I turn to the topic of delegation of statutory functions, which is a major part of the bill. The background is that the Australian Industrial Property Organisation is a division of the Department of Industry, Technology and Regional Development. The Director-General of the Australian Industrial Property Organisation also has statutory functions as the commissioner of patents, registrar of trade marks and registrar of designs. In order to allow the director-general to place more emphasis on his management responsibilities, the bill amends the Patents Act, the Trade Marks Act and the Designs Act to delegate the director-general's statutory functions to be carried out by the head of each of the relevant offices.

So far so good. The Australian Democrats have no issue with the amendments thus far. However, the bill goes further to allow those statutory officeholders to then delegate their powers and functions to any public service employee who is employed in the relevant office. Thus, public service employees—and they are not designated employees—would be able to summons witnesses, receive evidence on oath, orally or otherwise, require the production of documents or articles and award costs against a party to proceedings before the office.

We believe that it is simply not appropriate for such semi-judicial powers to be performed by any public service employee in the relevant office. As I have already mentioned, in the committee stage we shall move amendments which will require the class of public service employees who may exercise such powers in each of the relevant offices to be prescribed by regulation at least. We believe that the government should go thus far and consciously consider who should have these powers delegated to him or her so that we do not have wide open delegation of powers to the extent that the act currently provides, which we consider totally inappropriate.

The other point that I wish to raise is the matter of the powers of the registrar. The bill provides that the powers and functions of the head of each of the relevant offices, that is, the registrars of trade marks, designs and patents, are conferred under this act or any other act or `regulations made under this Act or any other Act'. It is this latter problem that we wish to address by another amendment.

The Australian Democrats find it inappropriate for the registrars' powers and functions to be capable of being increased, diminished or changed without the correct process of full parliamentary scrutiny. Thus, in the committee stage I will be moving an amendment to the bill to remove any conferral of registrars' powers by legislation, which means that, if these powers are to be changed, they must be changed by legislation and properly scrutinised and debated in this chamber.

There are a number of other matters contained in this bill that I wish to address briefly. The first is the extension of eligibility as a convention country. The current pieces of patent, trade marks and designs legislation each recognise a right of priority for convention applications, that is, applications made in countries which are a signatory to international conventions dealing with the protection of industrial property. This priority enables an application for a patent, trade mark or design in a convention country to be treated as if it had been filed in Australia on the same day.

The amendment to the Designs Act and to the Trade Marks Act enables regulations to be made declaring a country a convention country where a bilateral agreement has been entered into concerning the protection of industrial property rights. The Patents Act 1990 already makes provision for these purposes.

The next item in this bill that I wish to address is the correction of entries on the register of designs. This is a very sensible amendment which will enable the registrar of designs to correct an entry in the register for the purposes of correcting a clerical error or obvious mistake. This circumvents the expensive procedure which currently exists whereby an application of the registered owner of the design must be referred to the Federal Court or to a state supreme court to have changes made.

Finally, I come to the extension of the industry innovations program and the inclusion of a sunset clause. The amendments to this bill provide for an extension of the government's industry innovation program to December 1995. The industry innovation program comprises the 150 per cent tax concession for research and development, as well as a range of discretionary grants for innovation, research and development.

The Australian National Audit Office reviewed the administrative efficiency of the tax concession during 1993 and produced a very scathing report. The Auditor-General found it impossible to assess the effectiveness of the incentive provided by the Australian taxpayer to companies engaging in research and development because the responsible government instrumentalities—the Industry Research and Development Board and the Australian Taxation Office—had failed to set up any comprehensive assessment criteria for the scheme. It was, therefore, very difficult for anyone, including the Auditor-General, to determine whether the 150 per cent tax concession was worthwhile.

On the face of it, it is. There is probably a very good case to consider increasing it to 200 per cent in the forthcoming budget, as Singapore has done. We all know that the economy in Singapore is surging ahead, not least because of the performance of some of its innovative products which have been spawned by the superior research and development activities in that country. However, it is difficult to argue for the increase and to get the government to accept its responsibility to support the research and development activities of industrial enterprises when the bureaucrats responsible for administration and assessment do not provide us with adequate criteria and an adequate system to enable us to clearly assess the value of that concession.

The report that I mentioned was tabled in the Senate on 22 December 1993. At that time, I called upon the responsible minister, Senator Schacht, to provide the Senate with a progress report as soon as possible as to the remedial action which would be taken to rectify this extremely unsatisfactory situation. I regret to say that so far we have not heard anything further on this matter. Therefore, while the Australian Democrats welcome the government's continuing assistance to Australian industry to undertake research and development through this program and the complementary assistance of the 150 per cent tax concession, it would be reassuring to know that assessment criteria are now in place which are capable of indicating that further expenditure on research and development is producing results in assisting our industries to become more competitive in international markets.

As I indicated earlier, the Australian Democrats support the Industry, Technology and Regional Development Legislation Amendment Bill 1993. However, I hope that the government and the opposition will support the two amendments that I will be moving during the committee stage.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, the Industry Technology and Regional Development Legislation Amendment Bill 1993 seeks to make a number of uncontentious amendments to existing legislation within the portfolio of industry, technology and regional development. It contains amendments to the Designs Act 1906, the Patents Act 1990 and the Trademarks Act 1955 to facilitate administrative arrangements for the new Australian industry property organisation. It contains provisions for standardisation of convention country provisions in line with the Patents Act 1990, and also simplification of procedures for minor corrections of entries in the register of designs. It also provides for extension of the termination date to 31 December 1995 for the discretionary and generic technology grants scheme under the industry innovation program.

PARA.TAB: The coalition does not have any substantive objection to these amendments and will not be opposing the bill. Senator Spindler mentioned in his speech that he will be moving amendments, and the coalition will support those amendments as well.

However, the bill provides an appropriate opportunity to have a brief look at the important nature of industry policy and the forthcoming industry statement to be delivered by the new Minister for Industry, Technology and Regional Development, Senator Cook. We are not sure what is going to be in that industry statement because it appears that the recent change in minister is likely to lead to a different direction in the context of the policy.

That is indicative of the great confusion that this government has demonstrated over years in terms of the industry policy it is seeking to follow. Anyone who can follow what this government is thinking about in terms of the nature of industry policy, the role of government in its policy, looks in vain for any consistent pattern. That is indicative in particular of an overall lack of policy direction by this government, and of an increasingly weak, second-rate front bench which makes it impossible for any government to formulate good, strong and consistent policy direction.

TALK.START.PARA: —What are you babbling on about?

—I would not say too much, Senator Schacht. Although I did not name him in that context of the front bench, he would have to be a person that comes to the forefront of my mind. His disgraceful performance in relation to the Customs Service, which was acknowledged in the statement he made yesterday, provided ample testimony of this.

PARA.TAB: What we do know is what will not be in the industry statement, that is, any genuine attempt at the real reforms that are necessary in this country if we are going to make ourselves an internationally competitive nation on a sustainable basis. That involves reform in a range of major areas. The number one area, of course, is reform in industrial relations, because unless there is that reform in industrial relations and the necessary flexibility in labour market practices, one will not achieve the productivity gains or the other improvements that are necessary to improve our competitiveness and efficiency in those essential infrastructure type industries and sectors, such as telecommunications, transport, and the like. This Labor government seems really to have given up on these two crucial issues, that is, micro-economic reform following industrial relations, having failed adequately to address those issues over the last 10 years.

Whilst the government and its ministers constantly lecture business on being internationally competitive, the government religiously fails to practise what it preaches. A recent survey of 5,000 Australian businesses by the firm KPMG Peat Marwick identified labour oncosts as the most significant barriers to further investment in Australia. Sixty-one per cent of the respondents to the survey mentioned labour oncosts as a major inhibiting factor to further investment, and therefore, of course, to growth of their firms and industries.

As well as other government influences like labour costs and the failure of industrial relations policy, between 43 per cent and 50 per cent mentioned government charges. I hope Senator Schacht will note that uncertainty of government decision making was mentioned by no less than 47 per cent of the survey respondents as being a major inhibiting factor to the development of their businesses. That highlights very starkly what I said before: there has been this total inconsistency of government policy throughout the period of the Hawke and Keating governments which has held back Australia from realising the enormous potential that we would have if we were to get our act right.

Labour oncosts are one of the major impediments that Australian industry has to being world competitive, but other government imposed bureaucratic proposals—the superannuation guarantee levy, the training guarantee levy and the like—are very heavy imposts on business and impose restrictions on our ability to compete. I plead with the government to take into account in its industry policy statement to be brought down shortly that we cannot solve industry's problems by doling out money to it or by attempting to pick winners. That policy has been disastrous in the past. We need straightforward, across-the-board decisions that lead to cost reductions for business and industry and, therefore, provide the opportunity to increase their productivity and their competitiveness.

I am encouraged by the fact that Senator Cook's trade background, limited in time though it was, seems from his initial statements to have convinced him about the pointless nature of sectoral policies or handouts. I commend Senator Cook for his earlier remark on this subject that `the era of the handout is dead'. However, I caution him that rhetoric alone is absolutely insufficient and that we need substance to justify that correct assertion that he makes. If he has a look—as I hope he has done by now—at the costs of the various schemes and proposals in his new portfolio, he will find that a very large handout mentality remains, which is not doing Australian industry any good; indeed, it is doing the contrary.

TALK.START.PARA: —Which programs would you cut?

—Any new minister has a responsibility, as Senator Schacht presumably well knows, to look at his portfolio across the board. I hope that Senator Cook will do that. However, I suspect that, at the end of the day, once again the trade union movement and the Labor caucus will fail to embrace an internationally orientated and competitive industry structure. Instead, I can see every prospect of them patting themselves on the back, mouthing empty platitudes and rhetoric—as they did on industrial relations, corporate law and taxation reform—and simply allowing the throwing of more money at schemes rather than tackling the fundamental underlying problems that still bedevil so many sections of Australian industry.

PARA.TAB: We only have to look across the Tasman to New Zealand to see what can happen and the benefits that can be derived from a truly open, reformed and competitive nation. There, people are looking at six per cent economic growth; they are looking at sustained trade surpluses after their country being the absolute basket case of the Western world only five or 10 years ago so far as its competitiveness was concerned. At the same time, they are achieving those things in the context of a growing job environment for, although it is still far too high, nonetheless, there has been a progressive fall in unemployment.

Across the other side of the Pacific, the United States has a deregulated labour market and in the past 60 years unemployment there has never exceeded eight per cent. It is now under seven per cent. Investment and exports are rising strongly, and there is four per cent-plus economic growth. Authorities in the United States are even looking at the need for some increase in interest rates—though only to 3 1/4 per cent—to dampen any unsustainable growth in the economy.

Yet in Australia for the first time in four years we are starting to regain some confidence with 3 1/2 per cent growth, which of course is 2 1/2 per cent if one adjusts for population increases. But Australia still has a $17 billion current account deficit facing it this year, still has around 11 per cent unemployment, and still has the dreadful burden around its neck of a foreign debt that is of the order of $200 billion. So although I welcome the growth that is now starting to re-emerge, I must point out that in looking at the fundamentals of the Australian economy we really compare very badly with some of the other countries that I have just mentioned.

Certainly I acknowledge that there has been some improvement in our competitiveness, although most of it has been due to the devaluation of the Australian dollar. In the long term there is no way that one can build progressively and sustainably a nation's competitiveness just on the basis of devaluing one's currency. A devaluation of the currency in itself is initially a fall in a nation's standard of living.

Whilst there have been some improvements in our competitiveness and some micro-economic reforms, which I do not deny, this government fails to realise that it is just not good enough to be playing limited catch-up with our competition. As a nation we have to be getting ahead of our competition. All we managed to do throughout the 1980s was reduce the rate of our decline, not actually turn it around. Neighbours such as Hong Kong, Singapore and others in the Asian region, particularly in the South-East Asian region, now have higher per capita living standards than we do—a thought that would have been incomprehensible to us here in Australia 20 years ago—and continue to show much better future growth prospects.

So there is a great deal to be done in the whole area of industry reform. There is a great deal that industry itself has to do, but there is also much that government can do. In particular it can get out of the way of industry to enable it to get its costs down, to be more competitive and to compete internationally in the way that is absolutely essential if we want to have the increase in living standards and the quality of life to which we aspire.

Those matters are more importantly the subject for debate on another day when we see the whites of the eyes of the government's industry policy, but they are points that I wanted to make today in the context of the Industry, Technology and Regional Development Legislation Amendment Bill, which the opposition does not oppose. We will be supporting the amendments foreshadowed by Senator Spindler.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise briefly in this second reading debate on the Industry, Technology and Regional Development Legislation Amendment Bill to reply to the remarks made by various senators. First of all, I will comment on Senator Spindler's proposed amendments.

I think then we will be able to deal in one hit with all the Democrat amendments. The opposition has indicated its support for those amendments so there should be no need for a division or unnecessary debate.

I want to make a couple of remarks about Senator Short's contribution to this debate. The honourable senator mentioned the forthcoming industry statement. He also spoke about the policies of the government relating to the industry area as well as a number of other areas of the portfolio that are covered in what is, in effect, a mini-omnibus bill. I am a little astonished that Senator Short made remarks about the disarray in government policy and the different indications given by the government to the community about the expectations in the forthcoming industry statement. If Senator Short looks carefully at the statements made by the former minister, Mr Griffiths, and the new minister, Senator Cook, he will see that there is a quite genuine consistency.

Last year Mr Griffiths made it quite clear that the days of relying on high protection, on quotas, and on tariffs to protect industry in Australia—and therefore ending up with industry that is not international competitive—were finished; that that debate had gone. In consultation with industry, he was looking for ideas on how we can enhance the international competitiveness of our industries. Senator Cook, since taking over, has emphasised that there is no handout mentality and that we will always be looking at ways to enhance our international competitiveness.

There is no inconsistency between the two ministers. Certainly, when the statement is completed and presented to the people and the parliament, those opposite will note that it is an industry statement that sees Australian industry into the 21st century as being internationally competitive and technologically advanced, with Australians being able to maintain themselves by having an expanding manufacturing base that not only can service the needs of the Australian community but also can export to the world. We have all seen in recent years endless figures and statistics on how the level of Australian manufactures has been rapidly growing—the highest growing area of our exports overall.

I am a little surprised at the suggestion by Senator Short that we still have a handout mentality in the department and in our policies in areas of industry. (Quorum formed) I was making the point that the portfolio has a number of programs that are very beneficial to industry and are not part of a handout mentality. For example, one of them is the 150 per cent tax concession. All industries within the portfolio that I talk to are very supportive of that. They do not see it as being a handout mentality. They see it as a way of encouraging technology and scientific invention in this country. They also see it as a way of encouraging Australian firms to be more innovative and to develop products, through proper investment in R&D, that are not only able to be used in Australia but also are world competitive.

The bill also refers to an extension of the GIRD grants and the sunset clause. The government has committed further money to the end of 1995 for these grants to Australian industry to turn new ideas into products—an excellent scheme which has been well supported by industry. The scheme does not foster a handout mentality in those companies that cannot support themselves; it assists industry to develop good ideas over time to obtain a commercial or market outcome.

I reject Senator Short's accusation that the government is in disarray. Yesterday, I personally experienced the disarray of the opposition. I made a major announcement about the reform of the Australian Customs Service. DEBATE.TITLE: FOREIGN EVIDENCE BILL 1993FOREIGN EVIDENCE (TRANSITIONAL PROVISIONS AND CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS) BILL 1993

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 16 December 1993, on motion by Senator Sherry:
That these bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Foreign Evidence Bill has three purposes, as indicated by the minister in his second reading speech. Firstly, it is to provide new procedures for enabling authenticated foreign testimony to be admissible subject to certain safeguards; secondly, it is to implement The Hague Convention abolishing the requirement of legalisation for foreign public documents; and, finally, it is to re-enact, with minor changes, certain parts of the Evidence Act 1905.

PARA.TAB: Perhaps the most significant aspect of this bill is that it is an attempt to simplify the means by which foreign evidence can be introduced into criminal and some civil proceedings in Australian courts exercising federal jurisdiction. As I said, it also re-enacts, with some variations, the provisions of the Evidence Act dealing with the examination of witnesses abroad and the taking of evidence in foreign courts. As I have indicated, it also deals with the requirements of the international convention dealing with the authentication of foreign public documents.

This bill is designed to stand on its own, but it is being introduced by the government as part of a package of quite extensive reform of federal and, potentially, state evidence, if the states want to have uniformity. The Evidence Bill 1993 was introduced into the House of Representatives in December last year and, as I understand it, is due for a second reading debate next month. That bill basically rewrites the law of evidence at the federal level. The government is hoping that the states will follow suit and introduce complementary legislation with the ultimate aim of achieving broadly similar evidence laws in all Australian jurisdictions.

While the merits or otherwise of the Foreign Evidence Bill can be considered in isolation from the Evidence Bill, the relationship between the two bills does give rise to some technical issues concerning the application of other laws, which I will come to later. The bill is not opposed by the coalition because, broadly, the objects sought to be achieved by the bill are worth while. But there are some questions concerning the particular method by which the aims and objectives are to be achieved.

Part 2 of the bill re-enacts, with variations, part IIIB of the Evidence Act 1905. It sets out procedures for examination of witnesses outside Australia, pursuant to court order, after the commencement of proceedings in Australia. It applies to criminal and civil proceedings in Australian courts exercising federal jurisdiction. Given that, as I understand it, it essentially re-enacts existing law, it is uncontroversial.

Part 3 of the bill deals with foreign material being admissible in Australian courts without foreign witnesses having to give oral testimony in Australia. At the moment, there are very few situations where that can happen. As a consequence of a resolution of the National Complex White Collar Crime Conference in June 1992 and a resolution from that conference calling for action to reduce the need for foreign witnesses to be made available, this part 3 has been introduced. It is designed to improve the effectiveness of mutual assistance in criminal matters and to assist, therefore, in the prosecution of complex matters that involve foreign evidence. As I recall, that conference was organised by the National Crime Authority. I ask the minister whether that is right and whether Justice Phillips organised that conference.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes.

—He deserves to be given a mention today for the very sensible work that he did. Instigating this conference was a very sensible move, and it should be remembered that it was Justice Phillips who got that under way. Perhaps we would not have these changes today if we had not had that conference.

PARA.TAB: This part applies to criminal proceedings in Australian courts dealing with an offence against the laws of the Commonwealth. It applies to civil proceedings, but only those that are related to criminal proceedings—that is, one that arises from the same subject matter from which the criminal proceedings arose. A mechanism is provided for the provisions to apply to state courts dealing with state laws, if the state wants that to happen. That is part of the government's hope of achieving uniformity. No doubt the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs with its costs of justice inquiry will be pleased to see the passage of this legislation. That committee has noted time and time again the increased cost of justice that is occasioned by the lack of uniformity in a wide variety of laws around Australia.

A request for foreign testimony and accompanying exhibits has to be made by the Attorney-General. I assume that when a particular agency is looking for some material it has to notify the Attorney-General to make the particular request. The testimony needs to be certified by the foreign country. Once the material is before a court, the court must not allow the material to be adduced if the person who gave the testimony is in Australia and is able to attend the hearing, or if the evidence would otherwise have been inadmissible.

The court does have some discretion to exclude material. Specific matters are listed which the court has to take into account in exercising its discretion. One might ask `Why, under part 3, are the procedures limited to proceedings which involve, or have a relationship with, criminal proceedings, and why are the provisions designed for the benefit of law enforcement agencies only, rather than the accused or the defendant?'. Part 3 adds to the provisions of the Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters Act 1987. That act provides a legislative basis for Australia to enter into arrangements with other countries, whereby it can request and grant assistance in criminal matters. It seems that the practical opportunity for law enforcement agencies to be provided with foreign testimony derives from the relationship that has developed with a number of other countries since the passage of that act and associated bilateral treaties.

Part 4 of the bill contains a scheme similar to part 3 and allows the Australian Securities Commission to obtain testimony from its foreign equivalents in civil proceedings. The ASC has to be a party to those proceedings. The request can be made direct from the ASC to the foreign securities agency. Once the testimony is provided, the court's discretion to admit or decline to admit the material operates in the same way as the discretions under part 3. The Attorney-General's Department has indicated that the use of this part is intended to be limited to foreign agencies that have formal memoranda of understanding with the ASC. Currently, as I understand it, those memoranda exist with the relevant authorities in the United Kingdom, the United States of America and Hong Kong. If that list is incorrect, the minister might take the opportunity to let us know.

Under the Corporations Law the ASC has power to intervene in a variety of proceedings commenced between private parties. It is presumed that intervention of that nature would make the ASC a party to the proceedings for the purpose of part 4. To some extent, it seems incongruous that in those cases the ability to adduce testimony from foreign agencies should depend on whether the ASC has intervened. One should consider that the arrangement will apply, in practical terms, only with the countries referred to previously with whom the formal memoranda of understanding have been agreed to.

A significant point not readily apparent from reading the bill is the relationship of parts 2, 3 and 4 to state evidence laws. The difficulty will not be solved by the passage of the Foreign Evidence Bill 1993 because while parts 2, 3 and 4 of this bill apply to Australian courts exercising federal jurisdiction, the Foreign Evidence Bill 1993 applies to federal courts only. In a situation where a state court is exercising federal jurisdiction, the issue will arise where state laws dealing with foreign evidence and its reception by courts are excluded. Clause 18 of the bill seeks to preserve other laws for the purpose of part 2. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: This Part is not intended to exclude or limit the operation of any Australian law, or of any rule or regulation made under such a law, that provides for the examination of witnesses outside Australia for the purpose of a proceeding in Australia.

It might be determined that part 2 is so comprehensive in its terms that it covers the field in any event, thereby excluding other laws. Formulations seemingly protecting the application of other laws are provided for in parts 3 and 4. The wording in both cases is as follows:
This Part does not limit the ways in which a matter may be proved, or evidence may be adduced, under this Act (other than this Part) or any other Australian law.

The words `other than this part' are uncertain in scope. They might arguably exclude, in relation to part 3, for example, any state law that determines the admissibility of foreign testimony in criminal and related civil proceedings. Further, a `covering the field' argument might still be available in relation to parts 3 and 4. If state laws are excluded, it may eliminate laws which operate to admit foreign evidence more expediently than is provided for in this bill. For example, some state laws dealing with the admissibility of business records provide a useful means for the admission of certain categories of foreign evidence.

PARA.TAB: Part 5 deals with a recognition by Australian courts and public officials of certain foreign public documents. The Hague convention abolishing the requirement for legalisation of foreign public documents seeks to simplify the procedures for certification of public documents generated in one country and which are required for official use in another country. At present, certain public documents are required to be certified by the foreign embassy or consulate of the country where the document is required. The convention abolishes that practice, and provides for the issue of a certificate by the country which generated the document which is sufficient to authenticate the original document. The government has indicated it wishes to accede to the convention.

The bill implements the convention by requiring that Australian courts and officials recognise the certificate as evidence of authenticity of the document. It should be noted that court recognition is not limited to Australian courts exercising federal jurisdiction, but is applicable to courts exercising state jurisdiction. It would appear that that extension to state jurisdiction derives from the external affairs power of the constitution.

The Attorney-General's Department has advised that as a matter of practice foreign documents do not generally require formal legalisation in Australia. The convention is being acceded to, and these provisions implemented, so that the benefit of the convention can be claimed by those seeking to adduce Australian documents in other countries which are party to the convention. There does not seem to be much which is controversial in that.

Part 6 re-enacts, with some variations, part IIIC of the Evidence Act 1905. The part deals with a situation where Australian courts are taking evidence for use in foreign proceedings. The part provides that the Attorney-General may prohibit the taking of evidence in the interests of Australia's security. Unlike the Evidence Act 1905, the Attorney's power is not limited to civil and criminal proceedings. It is not entirely clear why that restriction existed in the Evidence Act 1905. However, there appears no justification for the distinction to remain on policy grounds. As I indicated earlier, the coalition does not oppose the bill.(Quorum formed)

TALK.START.PARA: —Today the Senate is debating the Foreign Evidence Bill 1993. This bill has three main purposes: first, to enable authenticated foreign testimony to be admissible in Australian courts; secondly, to implement The Hague convention which abolishes the requirement of diplomatic or consular legislation for foreign public documents; and, thirdly, to re-enact parts IIIB and IIIC of the Evidence Act 1905, the remainder of which is being repealed by the Foreign Evidence (Transitional Provisions and Consequential Amendments) Bill.

PARA.TAB: The central features of the bill address the need in our courts to be cost effective yet, in terms of legal rights, to have a protective mechanism to receive evidence taken in courts overseas. The most important aspect of this legislation and its potential impact on legal rights is contained in part III. In criminal and related proceedings, it will enable foreign testimony and exhibits which are authenticated in the prescribed manner to be admissible in evidence. This limits a party's right to cross-examine potential witnesses. A number of qualifications have been introduced to safeguard people's rights in the operation of this legislative scheme.

First of all, the evidence must have been taken on oath or under the caution that usually applies in the country where the evidence is taken. Secondly, the evidence must be certified by the court and must bear the seal of a minister of state in that country. Thirdly, the evidence must have been requested by the Attorney-General and certified by the Attorney-General. Fourthly, it is inadmissible if the person is in Australia and is able to attend. Fifthly, it is still subject to tests of admissibility. Sixthly, the Australian court in which the evidence is to be tendered has a discretion to reject the tender of the material if in the interests of justice it should be excluded.This discretion is fairly open-ended under subsection (2) of section 25.

The Australian Democrats place a great deal of reliance on this discretion of the court, and it is one of the reasons why we will be supporting this bill. Part IV of the bill which deals with proceedings instituted by the ASC has similar safeguards built in, except that the request must be made by the chairman of the ASC rather than the Attorney-General.

The minister's second reading speech claims the virtue of the bill will be that it will save time and money in complex cases where a great deal of foreign evidence is required. This is admitted, although I would like to return to this point a little later. Certainly the safeguards in sections 25 and 33 appear to be adequate to protect defendants' rights.

It should, however, be noted that part II of the bill allows for the examination of overseas witnesses by the court or parties to proceedings or by a foreign tribunal appointed by the court in Australia. The evidence so taken can be admissible in committal hearings and, if the court so directs, be tenderable in the criminal hearing that arises from the committal.

If, for example, a person whose evidence was taken under the mechanisms available under part II of the bill is still overseas at the time of the trial or has died, then it may still be admissible under relevant state and territory legislation and under this bill without some of the safeguards I have referred to that are available under part III. Given, however, that there is this residual discretion vested in the court to exclude the evidence if justice demands, then this shortfall in safeguards in our view is acceptable.

We have canvassed the views of the profession and the relevant bodies on this and have not been able to ascertain any serious concerns expressed by the legal profession. The genesis of the legislation seems to have been in the general trend for more international cooperation in matters of criminal law. The National Conference on Complex White Collar Crime held in June 1992 referred a number of resolutions to the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General and the National Crime Authority consultative committee on issues concerning the prosecution of white collar crime. Included in the resolutions was a call for legislation such as is found in this bill.

I take this opportunity to acknowledge the very valuable work Mr Justice Phillips has carried out in his all too brief sojourn in the capacity of Chairman of the NCA, which took him into a twilight zone between the judicial system and the political system. This was certainly one of the very worthwhile contributions that he has made in what I think is a fairly complex situation.

It was also noted by Mr Michael Rozenes, the Director of Public Prosecutions, at that conference that the obvious answer to the problem of obtaining and presenting overseas evidence is to use modern technology and to allow overseas witnesses to give their evidence directly by way of, for example, a satellite link. It would seem to me that this would allow for cross-examination in all cases. It is surely a preferred option to what is being offered in this bill, which I would call a poor man's vision of what is achievable in this area.

With advancing technology, I would express the hope that this bill will be fairly short lived and that we can look forward to better and technologically more sophisticated versions of proceedings which can achieve what this bill seeks to do. As I have said previously, subject to these comments, the Australian Democrats are pleased to support this legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am obliged to the minister. The information certainly was helpful. As I now understand the position—correct me if I am wrong—to employ this provision, defendants who want to have a witness examined overseas require a court order. That is, they need to make application to the court. The court then makes an order which goes to the Attorney-General, who in turn makes a request. The prosecution can employ that procedure. But added to that, the prosecution can go directly to the Attorney-General to make the request. So the prosecution has two avenues available, whereas the defence has only one. Is that right?

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Science and Small Business and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, that is correct. The provisions are broader for the prosecution.

—I can understand the reasons for that. Having experience of obtaining evidence from a witness overseas, I can see the benefit of this bill. However, where the defence encounters a more cumbersome procedure for applying to a court, perhaps some safeguard should be initiated, such as provision for an adjournment of the matter if the defence strikes a problem in obtaining an order.

PARA.TAB: If a defence lawyer is at the door of the court but cannot get his witness there, he will make an application to the trial judge, saying, `We have tried to get this person. We have only just got hold of him. We now want an order requesting the person be examined under this process'. The defence should not be prejudiced in any way by having to make this application at such a late stage. If the judge says, `No. You cannot have that witness examined', I suppose the defence has to box on and possibly look at an appeal. Has any thought been given to that?

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Science and Small Business and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that the court has discretion in this matter, but that is not determined in this bill. I say to Senator Ellison that, while I do not claim to be an expert on this bill or on these matters, the point he raises about ensuring that the defence is not disadvantaged because of having to get its information from overseas has some merit.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison Sen C.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Clause 25(2) deals with the discretion mentioned by Senator Spindler in relation to the giving of the direction as to whether foreign material can be adduced. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: Whether the exclusion of the foreign material would cause undue expense or delay.

That is something which really would apply to the prosecution, I suppose. But perhaps there is an opportunity to mention whether the defence might be prejudiced by the exclusion of the material. Subclause 2(b) makes mention of the probative value of the foreign material with respect to any issue that is likely to be determined in the proceeding.

PARA.TAB: Probative is something that the prosecutor would normally look to if he were trying to prove something. I wonder whether the defence should not get a mention there. One of the things we have to address our mind to is: if we exclude this, will it prejudice the defence? That could then heighten the way in which the court has to address any application at the court door by the defence for a witness to be examined overseas. I suppose a judge has discretion anyway in respect of late notice being given or an adjournment being asked for because something has happened at the last minute. But I wonder whether there should not be something included which mentions the prejudice to the defence.

I say that because an individual does not have the resources available to him or her, whoever is conducting the case, to get the evidence that the state has. The state has great resources at its disposal but the individual does not. I am wondering whether there should not be something to that effect mentioned. How would the minister see that being addressed in this subclause?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen The Hon C.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Science and Small Business and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —My advisers have brought this to my attention. Clause 25(2) states:

SPEECH.PARA: Without limiting the matters that the court may take into account in deciding whether to give such a discretion, it must take into account:

Paragraphs (a) to (d) of clause 25(2) then set out what must be taken into account. But the court has a wider discretion to take other things into account. The judge would have the discretion to take wider issues into account if the defence said that it was being disadvantaged. Of course, the judge has the discretion to weigh that up and make the appropriate decision. Paragraphs (a) to (d) are mandatory, and the court must take them into account. But subclause (2) also says:
Without limiting the matters that the court may take into account in deciding whether to give such a direction . . .
So the court has a wide discretion to deal with the point raised by Senator Ellison.

TALK.START.PARA: —Perhaps the matter could be covered by adding `(e) whether the exclusion of the foreign material would cause prejudice to either party'. That clearly would cover the prosecution because one does not want to prejudice the prosecution either. The minister says `other matters'. If one argues before a judge that other matters are allowed to be taken into account, the judge will say, `Yes, but I have got these four criteria which parliament has spelt out that it specifically wants me to take into account'. These other peripheral matters do not enjoy the same status as the four that are enumerated here.

PARA.TAB: Prejudice in the exclusion of evidence has always been a key criterion. The judge always asks about the probative value versus the prejudicial content. The prior record, for instance, of a defendant might be, to some extent, probative that that defendant has a disposition to stealing. But, of course, the prejudicial aspect far outweighs the probative value.

Prejudice is not really canvassed. The criteria to be taken into account are good, but they are directed more to the administrative aspects—the expense, the delay. The other three are perhaps in a different vein, but the question of prejudice is not really covered. I ask the minister what the government's attitude would be to including a subclause that the question of prejudice be entertained.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Science and Small Business and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —When Senator Ellison was raising these matters, I asked my officers whether we could take account of his concerns without accidentally shooting a foot off somewhere else. We have to be very careful with technical matters in bills such as this. I have asked my officers to have a look at a possible form of words. I do not know whether it will deal with Senator Ellison's matter or satisfy his concerns, but we will have a look at that. While my officers are looking at that, I suggest that we deal with other contributions to this committee stage.

—This might be the time for the minister to come back to the point he started to make when he was responding to the second reading debate. My first query raised the applicability of this bill to courts exercising federal jurisdiction.

—I have just been given a form of words for a proposed new subclause (e) which I will outline to Senator Ellison. It would read, `whether the exclusion of the foreign material would cause substantial prejudice to the defence'.

—The prosecution might have something to say, too, on prejudice. Prejudice does not come under `undue expense or delay' in subclause (d). The extent to which the material could be challenged under (c) touches on it. The probative value in (b) is perhaps not so relevant to the question of prejudice as to the worth of the evidence. The words `the extent to which the foreign material provides evidence that would not otherwise be available' in (a) skirt around it. I simply put it to the minister that the words `substantial prejudice' might indicate to the court that it has to be something of great moment before there has to be an order. In other words, it has to be absolutely crucial to the defence before the court will make an order in its favour.

PARA.TAB: What we are looking at here is a question of degree. In the defendant's eyes, something which is important is just as crucial as something which is essential because it is the straw on the camel's back. How many straws do we have to put on the back before we break it? That is the problem I have with the word `substantial'. The word `prejudice' is perhaps sufficient because if something is prejudicial, it is prejudicial. It is like being pregnant—you cannot be half pregnant. If it is prejudicial, then it is undesirable, and it is undesirable that it be prejudicial to both the prosecution and the defence because justice requires that prejudice have no place. I inquire as to the government's thoughts on that.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Science and Small Business and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that it is important to keep the word `substantial' there. It is particularly important that we consider the sensitivities of other countries, especially if those countries already receive large numbers of mutual assistance requests. If requests were able to be directly made by defence lawyers, it is possible that the number of such requests could, with time, dramatically increase and endanger goodwill established with those countries. We believe it is important to have the word `substantial' there so that it is an issue—the judge has to be convinced that it is a substantial matter. We are willing to put that in as an (e), but we must have `substantial' in the clause.

—The problem is that the prosecution has this unfettered aspect of its request because the Attorney-General could simply make the request. The prosecution makes frequent requests. That uses up all the brownie points, so to speak, of the foreign countries. Defence lawyers come along—or the defendants themselves; we cannot exclude the fact that people appear in person—and say that there is a person, as was the case that I dealt with in Miami, who is not willing to come to Australia. I needed an order for that person to have his testimony taken and for it to be available to be adduced in the hearing. In the hearing I was involved in, there was no way of getting that testimony at the time. It is indicative of the problem that we face. The Attorney-General can do it willy-nilly for the prosecution, but a bar is being placed in the way of the defendant.

PARA.TAB: I can appreciate what the minister is saying in keeping good relations with other states. We do not want to overstay the welcome, so to speak. But the problem we have is that there must be some balance between the way the courts administer this. The court says that it is okay for the prosecution to have unfettered use of this, but when it comes to the defence, it really has to have a big point before it is used. I appreciate that we would not use it for minor matters or for matters of no great moment because that would be an abuse of the system. It could be employed to obtain all sorts of adjournments and it could be a ploy by the defence. I appreciate that. But if it is to be prejudicial, if anything is considered to be prejudicial by the court, then it becomes very serious.

The term `substantially prejudicial' is perhaps an accent on the term `prejudicial'. But if the court said, `We find that excluding this evidence is only prejudicial to the defence; it is not substantially prejudicial', then the defendant standing in the dock would think, `That is pretty good; I have to actually have my head on the block before the court will give me the order that I seek'. That is really what the minister is asking the court to do. The result could be for the court to say, `We find that to exclude this evidence would be prejudicial, but we do not think it would be substantially prejudicial'. I find that to be a great problem.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise briefly to support what Senator Ellison is saying. It seems to me that we have the safeguard of the court. It is unlikely that the court will deal with the matter or allow a matter to go ahead if it considers that the defendant's case is vexatious. The concern that has been expressed about diplomatic niceties could perhaps be reconsidered in this situation. The necessity to ensure that the defendant's rights are safeguarded in Australian courts must take precedence.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Science and Small Business and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —After further discussion with my advisers, we will proceed with proposed clause (e) and we will delete the word `substantial'. I trust this is not a loophole which 100,000 legal buses will drive through and so on. If it is, we will be back here to amend it. In all these cases experience is always the ultimate determinant and we always reserve the right to amend in light of experience. Senator Ellison spoke persuasively to his case, so I am more than happy that the amendment be moved by him—noting that we drafted it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison Sen C.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am obliged to the minister. In respect of the Foreign Evidence Bill 1993, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 25, page 10, at end of subclause (2), add the following word and paragraph:
"; and (e)whether exclusion of the foreign material would cause prejudice to the defence".

In relation to the abuse of this subclause, it has been my experience over some time that cases which will have a need for this provision are few and far between—although they are becoming more common. I can give that assurance. Hopefully it will be a provision which will not be abused. As Senator Spindler correctly says, I am sure the courts will act to ensure that it does not.

PARA.TAB: Amendment agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —Perhaps now is the appropriate time for the minister to raise the question of this being an act that applies to courts exercising federal jurisdiction and the difficulties that might arise in that respect. The point that was raised was whether in a state court exercising federal jurisdiction the situation might be that the state laws dealing with foreign evidence and its reception by the courts is excluded.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Science and Small Business and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not excluded.
—You are quite sure?
—Yes. I am advised that the state laws are specifically preserved—
—I think I will just accept the argument that the minister or the officials do not accept the queries that were raised.
—You have doubt that they are excluded, or that they are not preserved? Is that your query?
—Yes.
—I am advised that they are preserved. I suppose it is a matter that we assert that and you assert something different. I am sorry, but that is the advice given to me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill 1993 makes some small changes to the higher education legislation which the opposition does not oppose. They are well argued for in various documents, not least the December report about higher education funding in the 1994-96 triennium circulated by the Department of Employment, Education and Training. However, we do see some serious flaws in this legislation. I will, as succinctly as I can, on behalf of the opposition, refer to these, and move a second reading amendment highlighting one flaw in particular which we regard as unsatisfactory; that is, the fact that there are no new places in this legislation for Victoria, South Australia, Tasmania and the Northern Territory. The opposition regards this as being insufficiently explained by the government. The appearance is that the Commonwealth government is directly excluding from growth those three states, which include the state that I represent, and the Northern Territory.

PARA.TAB: I will deal first with the higher education contribution scheme. This legislation will correct some anomalies and reinforce the administrative handling of tax file numbers within the higher education contribution scheme system. The opposition sees no objection to the proposals in this legislation for making these adjustments.

It is worth recalling, though, that only last December when we were last sitting, the opposition very significantly and successfully opposed two of the government's proposals on the higher education contribution scheme. One proposal was that a double rate of HECS liability be accrued to some students. That is no longer to be the case. The other proposal was that a 1 1/2 times rate of HECS be accrued to those who were not making, as the government put it, sufficient progress. This has also been abandoned. These serious modifications to HECS would have been to the detriment of Australia's students and the whole of our education system. The opposition is glad that the Senate blocked those two government proposals. But, in this case, we support the government's changes.

The second issue I refer to is open learning. I am sure it is a disappointment to senators from all sides that there has not been the level of enrolments in open learning that was envisaged both 12 months ago when this open learning initiative first operated, and six months ago when estimates were made with regard to the 1994 year. So it is disappointing that, as a direct result of lower enrolments, we have to see in this legislation an adjustment of the moneys to be passed to the open learning initiative. Nevertheless, I am glad to see that for the triennium we have the same overall commitment of moneys for this area. I do hope that marketing, promoting the credibility of the scheme and other initiatives will lead to increased enrolment in open learning in the coming months. It is a great opportunity for many—not least, mature age students and those in areas distant from our capital cities—to take on higher education studies.

The third area I wish to deal with is the extra $51.7 million to be spent over three years to enable Australia's universities to meet their superannuation guarantee levy obligations. Of course we would not deny the universities this money, but I take the chance to remind the Senate that free enterprise—which employs the great bulk of Australians—cannot dip into taxpayers' money for $51.7 million in the way that our universities can. It is the opposition's view that the government has not responsibly taken account of the additional cost to employers in the private sector of the superannuation guarantee levy and that this levy will have a detrimental effect on the numbers of employed Australians. But for the public sector, seeking this additional money is a natural outcome of the law of the land as it now stands.

The fourth area I wish to mention is the area in which we have some difficulties with the government's position: the provision of new places within all of our universities. Reference is made to this in a number of points in the report Higher education funding for the 1994-96 triennium as distributed by the then Minister for Employment, Education and Training, Mr Beazley. This is quite a detailed and comprehensive report. On page 31, reference is made to principles underlying the allocation of 1996 growth. Subsequent sections that relate to the operating grants of the universities talk about the redefinition of targets and so on.

These pages do not adequately explain the government's intentions to have new places in only a few states and no new places at all in Victoria, no new places at all in South Australia, no new places at all in Tasmania and no new places at all in the Northern Territory. A number of my colleagues immediately twitched their political noses and asked, `Is the Labor government in Canberra singling out a number of states where there are Liberal governments and, on political grounds, denying them growth in 1996?'.

The Liberal and National parties are not satisfied with the explanation that the government has given, although there was a sort of wave of the hand in the other place when the then Minister for Employment, Education and Training, Mr Beazley, appealed in his second reading speech for equity and talked about population growth trends, the lower take-up of enrolments as a percentage of population and so on. But this has not been made clear.

I speak very plainly as a senator for South Australia: why should South Australia in 1996 get zero growth in university places? No doubt the Commonwealth, government ministers and party colleagues will try to pin this situation on those states themselves and mislead the public into thinking that these outcomes are a result of Liberal governments rather than a decision of this Labor Government here in Canberra. Accordingly, on behalf of the opposition I move:
At the end of motion, add "but the Senate:

SPEECH.PARA: (a)expresses its concern that no provision has been made in the amended operating grant for 1996 for allocation of new undergraduate places in Victoria, South Australia, Tasmania or the Northern Territory; and
(b)calls on the Government to ensure that the criteria underlying the allocation of new funded student places are applied consistently and equitably across the States and Territories".
In support of what I have just said, I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a press release from the Victorian Minister for Tertiary Education and Training, Mr Storey.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The document read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: From the Office of the Minister for Tertiary Education and Training
Tuesday, 8th February, 1994
CWLTH. DISCRIMINATES AGAINST VICTORIA IN UNI. PLACES
Demand for university places in Victoria is rising contrary to the downward national trend according to the Victorian Minister for Tertiary Education and Training, Haddon Storey.

Mr Storey's comments follow reports of national trend figures that inaccurately suggest demand for university places is down in all states. The number of applications in Victoria rose this year from 66,207 to 66,782 with a continuing high level of unmet demand for places.
Mr Storey expressed concern that many Victorians would miss out on a university place because of Federal Government funding policies.
"The Federal Government has chosen to ignore community demand and is playing politics with the allocation of university places between states," Mr Storey said.
"Under the Commonwealth's funding plans for the 1994-6 triennium extra university places will be allocated away from Victoria and in 1996 no new university places will be available to Victoria."
Mr Storey said this meant Commonwealth discrimination against Victoria in university funding policies would continue.

"Since 1989 higher education expansion in Australia had been financed by students through HECS fees with approximately 28% from Victorian students, yet only 20% of these monies returned to Victoria as extra university places," he said.
"In effect, Victorian students will continue to subsidise extra places in other states despite the fact that Victoria's level of unmet demand is higher than any other state," Mr Storey said.
"Simon Crean says he sees nothing wrong with shifting resources from Victoria even though Victoria cross subsidises other states by around $800 million per year."

"What he does not say is that demand for university places in Victoria is climbing against the national trend, with unmet demand continuing despite the provision of an additional 4,500 places over 1993 and 1994 funded by the Victoria Government," he said.
Mr Storey said Victoria was not only being penalised for successfully encouraging young people to continue their education it was being `equalised', or socially engineered.
"Victoria is Australia's research capital and the home of a large number of its knowledge industries," Mr Storey said.

"Given that Victoria also has the highest workforce proportion in professional occupations, the state requires a continuing high level of participation in university studies and employer and student demand reflects this.
"These facts have been ignored by the Commonwealth.

"Mr Crean is saying that he sees nothing wrong with the redirection of places away from Victoria in the face of this demand. The Victorian Government rejects his proposals as a blatant form of social engineering," he said.

TALK.START.PARA: —In this statement Mr Storey, the Victorian minister, amongst other things, said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Federal Government has chosen to ignore community demand and is playing politics with the allocation of university places between states.

I note that he appeals directly to the minister. Of course, Mr Crean, the newly appointed Minister for Employment, Education and Training, is a Victorian. It is very sad that the first legislation he handles in the parliament in this area is denying his own state.

PARA.TAB: I appeal to Mr Crean, not just in the terms of Mr Storey's justified statements with regard to Victoria. I also make an appeal to Mr Crean and the government in regard to what I call the centralising years of the Labor government under Mr Dawkins, which unfortunately continued under the minister following him, Mr Beazley. I appeal to Mr Crean to break free of that centralising objective of those preceding ministers that has brought the Labor Party and this Commonwealth government into such disrepute in our higher education institutions.

I appeal to Mr Crean to allow decisions to be decentralised and to allow some degree of autonomy to be regained by our university councils. We have had too many years of centralisation. All wisdom does not reside with the minister in Canberra, nor does it reside solely with his advisers from the Department of Employment, Education and Training. There is a great deal of experience at the level of a university council or a vice-chancellor's department, and there is room for initiative. Throughout all these years, the policy of the Liberal and National parties to decentralise and return autonomy to universities has stood in contrast to government policy. We trust those people who have, because of their experience, attained positions of leadership within our universities. I appeal to minister Crean to take notice of our better approach and to draw a distinction between his way of handling higher education matters and that of his predecessors.

There is another bias in the criteria set out from page 31 onwards in the government's statement and it works against mature age students to the advantage of school leavers. School leavers are defined as those who apply to come to a university within two years of completing year 12—a totally acceptable definition. However, the government feels that an insufficient number of places have been set aside for school leavers, despite the fact that they get the great bulk of university allocations, particularly for first year places. Therefore, this centralising minister of this centralising government has told the universities that a quota will apply to mature age students and that the system must be adjusted to favour school leavers.

I have no brief other than to open up the doors to all those who want to come into our universities—be they school leavers or mature age students. In 90 per cent of cases, mature age students are coming to our universities for the first time. For the bulk of them it is their first chance, at age 25, 30 or 40, to enrol at a university. Senator Bell and other senators in the chamber will know that often they are the most successful undergraduates and go on to achieve honours, masters and other postgraduate degrees. They are very successful students because they are well motivated and come with a great deal more experience than some school leavers.(Quorum formed)

Before the call for a quorum, I was appealing to Victorian, Tasmanian, South Australian and Northern Territory senators to note that this government has made no provision for growth in their states and territories in the 1996 year. I believe that those government senators who have now joined the debate ought to take up that matter in both caucus and in the other decision making processes of government.

There must be a fair and genuinely equitable place in the sun for both mature age students and school leavers entering our universities. The best way to ensure this is to allow institutions to open their doors to whomever they wish on whatever basis they wish—the policy of the Liberal-National party coalition. The only criticism this policy has generated is the thin edge of the wedge argument. The argument is that in subsequent years, if we allow universities to charge fees for school leavers and mature age students in addition to the places provided by the Commonwealth, that wedge might become wider and wider.

The coalition gives an undertaking that in government it will always guarantee an assured, predictable number of Commonwealth provided places in our universities and that institutions will be given the freedom to open their doors on whatever basis they think fit. At the moment this Labor Government prevents all our universities taking such a course. Such an undertaking as that suggested by the coalition would particularly help mature age and part-time students, which is the group the government is picking on in its high-minded appeal for more places for school leavers. I commend the amendment to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Regional Development. I refer the minister to Ford Australia's announcement that it will close the Homebush motor vehicle plant and discontinue production of the Capri model. Is the minister aware that the New South Wales Labor leader, Bob Carr, has called for a joint federal-state government rescue package for the New South Wales plant? Is the federal government considering such a rescue package? Does the minister see Ford's decision as a sign of confidence in Australia's economic recovery? What impact will the decisions have on our elaborately transformed manufacturing exports and imports?

—I have not seen the statement by the New South Wales Labor leader, Bob Carr, as Senator Short has reported it; but doubtless I will. I will be delighted to discuss his proposal with him when it is put before me. The announcement by Ford Australia today is unfortunate for the approximately 400 employees of Ford at Homebush who face unemployment when the Laser production facility at Homebush closes in September this year. But I note that Ford has pledged in public comments to work with the unions and employees to find alternative employment. I can say that we will, under the motor vehicle labour adjustment program, assist in that process too.

PARA.TAB: Senator Short asked me whether this announcement by Ford is an indication of confidence in the recovery. It is not a commentary on the state of the economy; it is a commentary more on the state of the motor vehicle market in Australia and the export potential and export gains of motor vehicle manufacturers in Australia. The figures on the recovery given by the Treasurer last week and provided to the Senate by me in answer to a question last week about further economic growth, continuing low inflation, further growth in employment, and so on—all the positive indicators—remain true. That is the scenario we are looking at in terms of recovery.

Ford's Laser is assembled at Homebush from packs imported from overseas in knocked-down condition. The Australian content is estimated at about 50 per cent. One of the problems for Ford is that it has not been able to hold market share, although market share of other small cars in Australia, notably the Corolla, is about the same as it was right back to 1990—give or take a few percentage points—when the two were locked in fierce competition. So it really is a commentary on the competitive nature of the domestic car market.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is nothing to do with your government's policies?

—No. The Corolla, which has held its market share the most, is fully manufactured in Australia. It is not assembled from knocked-down kits imported from overseas. The story of the Australian car industry, which remains a ringing endorsement of the industry—the levels of productivity, the improvement in quality and the reduction in manufacturing costs it has been able to achieve—is to be seen in the export market, where exports last year increased by 20 per cent to now register $1.5 billion. This is an adjustment in the market due to commercial factors and is not a commentary on the overall state of the economy. It can be said that the commitment of Ford to concentrate now on core production suggests that that company's future in this country is assured.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I note that the minister said in his response that he would be happy to consider any proposal from Mr Carr. I repeat one of the questions that he did not address in my earlier question—namely, is the government considering such a rescue package? I also draw his attention to the statement today by Ford Australia president, Mr John Ogden, when he said:

QUESTION.PARA: We are concerned, not just for Ford, but the whole industry will have trouble at 15 per cent (tariff), unless there's a whole lot of reforms to help us get the costs down.

Will the minister give us an assurance that the Labor government will enact a whole lot of reforms to help get the costs down as part of its industry statement?
