TALK.START.PARA: —As the question suggests, I am putting together an industry statement for a vision of industry policy development in Australia for the next 10 years. All the things that I have said are about making this a more competitive country in the international trading environment. That will be a feature of the industry statement. It sits ill from the opposition to raise the question of tariffs because it went to the election last on a zero tariffs option which would have wiped out the car industry in Australia and there would have been no jobs in the car industry in Australia had the opposition enacted its election promise.

—Mr President, I rise on a point of order. The minister knows full well that he is grossly misleading the Senate by implying that. He knows full well that the opposition's tariff policy at the last election was in conjunction with a whole lot of reforms that John Ogden is talking about. I ask him to be honest in his answers.
—Order! There is no point of order. You are blatantly debating the issue.

—Mr President, I rise on a point of order. The minister himself was debating the point. The issue did not relate to the opposition policy at the last election; so I point out to you, Mr President, that the minister himself was debating the point, not Senator Short.
—It is easy to see that it is broadcast day today. There is no point of order.

—Those opposite squeal because they are caught. There would be no car industry in Australia had the tariff policy they went to the election on been enacted. That is understood by the car industry in this country as well as the workers in that industry.

PARA.TAB: It was just Friday of last week that Mitsubishi Australia announced a commitment to Australian manufacturing that takes it well into the next century. Toyota Australia has committed itself to manufacturing in the next century, as has Holden. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Regional Development. What are the employment implications of the Ford closure? How will Victorian plants be affected? What consultation was there between the government and the union before this announcement was made, and what is the longer term future for car manufacturing in Victoria?

—I did not get all those questions down. Let me go back to the start and say that at a press conference this morning the president of Ford Australia, John Ogden, announced that for 1993 its after tax operating profit was $44 million, which expressed in before tax terms is an increase on the previous year of $113 million. The company had made a decision to remove from its operations its loss making elements, and this has created an after tax profit of $44 million.

PARA.TAB: The company has planned to discontinue manufacture of the Capri in Victoria and to close its Homebush plant in Sydney, New South Wales. The Capri production will cease in May. Sales in the US of that motor vehicle have fallen below the viable threshold that the company has set, and workers on the Capri production line will continue in work, as will that plant, on Falcon production. The Laser, which is assembled, as I have said, from knocked-down kits and imported into Australia, is, in the company's view, no longer economically viable. Production of the Laser will end in September of this year when a new generation Laser will be fully imported from Japan.

The company has also said that approximately 400 workers will be out of work as a result of closure of the Homebush plant and that it is not anticipating any unemployment in Victoria as a consequence of the company's decision there. Ford has committed itself to work with the unions and the employees to help find work, provide retraining and provide outplacement services. Ford, as the passenger motor vehicle market leader with the Falcon, is committed to continuing its core business of Falcon, Fairmont, LTD and Falcon commercial productions in Australia, and it has expressed a desire to continue to lead in the domestic market.

The government reaction to this statement is, as I said in answer to an earlier question, that it is unfortunate and regrettable for the workers concerned that this decision has been made. The government's motor vehicle plan labour adjustment package, which offers a range of services and assistance, will now be made available in the form of wage subsidies, vocational training of up to 12 months and relocation assistance, and the government will talk to Ford and the unions about helping those redundant workers.

It is also particularly difficult in these circumstances that news of this redundancy was leaked in advance, meaning that some workers woke up this morning and read it for the first time in their newspapers. That prevented Ford from being able to break the news itself, as it wanted to initially, to its own employees. Therefore, it is deplorable that whoever leaked that has created such trauma and difficulty for the human relations necessary to deal with an adjustment such as this smoothly.

On Friday of last week Mitsubishi announced a commitment for further generation car manufacture in Adelaide, taking it well into the next century. That is a $550 million investment in the car manufacturing industry in Australia. Toyota Australia has done the same and built a purpose-built greenfields site at Altona in Victoria, making Australia the centre of Asia-Pacific production for that company. Holden has made significant investment in exports as well.

Last year we increased exports of motor vehicles and motor vehicle parts to the value of $1.5 billion, a 20 per cent rise, showing that the export market is improving and has improved dramatically. It is unfortunate for Ford that the Capri was not able to hold up to the necessary level as an export car in the competitive US market, but it has meant that the company has improved its quality standards significantly. Productivity per head of employee is dramatically up and costs of production are dramatically down. With the commercial factors—(Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Regional Development. Did the president of Ford tell the minister last week of the company's intention to close the Laser and Capri assembly lines? Did the minister know that the unions had not been informed about these closures? Is he aware that there were urgent talks about the Homebush closure at the Labour Council of New South Wales this morning? Can he give the Senate a guarantee that Ford is not acting now to pre-empt the new retrenchment provisions of the Industrial Relations Reform Act?

—The Ford Motor Company did me the courtesy of advising me on a commercial-in-confidence basis that it had made a decision to take action. It also advised me of the process that it intended to follow in order to ensure that proper consultation and involvement in the decision by the relevant unions and the workers would be undertaken, and what labour adjustment policies it had to help those workers thus affected.

PARA.TAB: It is not appropriate for the government, which at various times holds commercial-in-confidence material, to act on that material and inform others. I was advised quite properly by Ford, as it was obliged to do, and I recognise the courtesy it paid me. It was Ford, as the decision maker, which undertook by its own proposal to consult the unions and the workers. It would have done so in an appropriate manner and in an orderly way had not news of the proposed changes been leaked in advance. That is not a condemnation of Ford; that is a condemnation of whoever leaked the information.

It is passing strange that one of the shadow ministers, Mr Prosser, was running around the gallery last night making exactly the same points as are inherent in Senator Chapman's question—whether I went off and consulted the unions, and so forth. One can only conclude that there was a trite and rather weak political point being made. In the circumstances, that is pathetic. I do not know whether Mr Prosser is the leaker, but for him to exploit the difficulty of this company and the misery of its employees who are facing unemployment for pathetic political gain is a reflection on him, his responsibility and the behaviour of the opposition in dealing with significant and important events. The government conducted itself properly and appropriately in the circumstances and I am confident that the company and the unions will cope with this difficult time in a similar way.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I direct the minister's attention to the last point of my question, which he completely ignored in his answer. Can he give the Senate a guarantee that Ford is not acting now to pre-empt the new retrenchment provisions of the Industrial Relations Reform Act?

—When I am asked six or seven questions in a row and have to answer them in four minutes, I cannot cover each one of them. It is not for me to give an undertaking about what Ford will do. Ford's advice to me on the question of retrenchment policy is that it had a harmonious and confident relationship with its unions. It believes that it can manage this matter properly. There was never any suggestion of it attempting or wanting to break any industrial law or order. I accept that, knowing the record of the industry, the unions and the employees. In many respects, they are a case example of parties working together under the federal government's industrial relations legislation to improve productivity and quality in a cooperative manner.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations. Is the minister aware of an article in yesterday's Australian Financial Review reporting the decision of the Full Bench of the Federal Court dealing with the issue of compensation for wrongful dismissal? How does that decision sit with the government's new Industrial Relations Reform Act?

—I am aware of the Australian Financial Review article. This decision appears to reverse the common understanding that award provisions which preclude unfair dismissal are incorporated into an employee's contract of employment. In practice, this understanding has allowed an employee to seek the contractual remedy of damages separate from any penalty for breach of award. The decision is likely to have a limited impact on the new remedies under the Industrial Relations Reform Act, which will give employees a legislative right to pursue compensation if their employment is terminated in one of the following ways: without a reason; with a reason which is harsh, unjust or unreasonable; or for an invalid reason.

PARA.TAB: After considering the merits of an application, the industrial relations court will be able to order an employer who has dismissed an employee unlawfully to reinstate the employee or to pay the employee compensation. Such a court order is intended to put employees in as near to the same position as they would be if their employment had not been terminated.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Health. I refer the minister to his package of health reforms and the leaflet detailing these reforms that he circulated for discussion. Is he aware of the universal criticism coming from the health system of these so-called reforms? Is he able to name any organisation that supports these reforms, other than the private health insurers? Does he agree with comments made by a wide range of individuals and organisations that his proposals threaten the stability and equity of Medicare? In the face of such criticisms, will he withdraw these proposals and start afresh?
—I am certainly aware that there is a lot of criticism of these proposals.
—Who is in favour of them?

—Just keep quiet and listen, and I will get around to you. I will not miss you today, I promise you that, Senator Herron. I expected criticism from vested interests on both sides of the argument. That is what we get whenever we seek change. We will always get entrenched opposition. On the right I have the AMA and Senator Herron, who want no change and who want the right for the top quartile in each specialty to charge whatever they like, and thus extend the gap between the schedule and their charges. That is what is happening. That will turn people off private health insurance. I understand that. The AMA is a union representing its members. It represents its highest paid and most powerful members very well, so naturally it will take that course.

PARA.TAB: On the other side, a lot of people in my own party and in the trade union movement simply say to themselves that Medicare has been a great success—which it has—but who therefore say that we can never change anything. In my view, after 10 years it is appropriate that we have a look at a system—any system—and if it has got strains and stresses around the edges, we should see what we can do about it. In my view it is not good enough to say, `We will have no change', when we have to face the fact that in public hospitals around Australia there are people who are in pain and discomfort and who are waiting too long for treatment.

I want to do something about them—not just today, but over the next decade and beyond. I want to look to that public system and make sure that it can handle everyone that it cannot handle today, and all those people who will be added to it in the future. I believe that, in order to plan for that over the next decade, I at least need to somewhere near stabilise those who are in private health insurance. That is the only aim. Over the next couple of years I intend to convince the government to have a massive recommitment to infrastructure in public hospitals; in other words, to Medicare.

I believe that we have to plan for that properly. We cannot continue to see a never ending drop in the numbers who are in private health insurance, because the money that they put into the system has to come from somewhere. Every year they are putting in a couple of billion dollars that we are going to have to find from somewhere, if we do not find it from private health insurance. That means a further strain on the public purse. I am worried about the capacity not just of this government but of future governments to be able to meet that kind of commitment.

So yes, I want to see the numbers stabilised but, more importantly, I want to recommit the government to having a massive rebuilding of infrastructure to make sure that the public sector does not continue to miss out in areas such as day surgery. Day surgery has become a private sector preserve, and I want to make sure that we get into that.

I noted with interest yesterday's statement from those representing the Doctors Reform Society—which was contrary to their statement before Christmas—that they are not on side with this. I understand that they are coming under pressures, and why should they not? The Doctors Reform Society has a belief that we should have nationalised medicine. That is a view that the Labor Party government has not shared, and will not be sharing. But they are entitled to that view, and I can understand why they would put it. I do not expect to have organised support. If I did, I think I would be a complete mug.
Senator Lees interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Lees thinks that a couple of consumer organisations made up of 50 people who call themselves consumers own an industry. I have to tell Senator Lees that they do not. People own the industries, and the people of Australia do not seem to think that what I am doing is wrong at all. Senator Lees will find that out over time, but usually it takes her a bit longer than some of the others.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Senator Collins. I draw the minister's attention to increasing speculation in industry and the rural media. Can the minister advise the Senate of his intentions in relation to the government's commitment to review the statutory arrangements for the meat and livestock industry?

—I am aware that Senator Jones is, understandably, concerned about the Queensland implications for this now multi-billion dollar industry to Australia. Last night I was able to meet in Sydney with representatives of the peak industry groups from the meat industry and with the AMLC board. I discussed with them their views of the future of this industry in the post-GATT environment.

PARA.TAB: The industry is looking forward with a realistic sense of optimism to the opportunities that have opened up under the successful conclusion of the GATT agreement. I know that Senator Cook will blush when I say this, but there was a great deal of recognition and praise last night for the role he played in the conclusion of those negotiations. The industry did say—

TALK.START.PARA: —Was this held at the John Curtin hotel?

—It was held at the AMLC headquarters in Sydney, which Senator Alston's backbench would claim was their constituency. They did say that they appreciated the late afternoon briefing sessions prior to the meetings the next day to ensure that government and industry acted jointly on this issue. There is a very keen appreciation that a great deal of work now has to be done, and will be done, by Senator McMullan in exploiting the opportunities. Last night the point was made that it is only opportunities that have been created, and in order to get the benefits, industry and government, acting together, will have to exploit those opportunities and work very hard to do so. The government's concern is to ensure the most effective and appropriate arrangements are in place for the meat and livestock industry in order for Australia to benefit from this.

PARA.TAB: The Industry Commission is currently finalising its report into the meat and livestock industry, and it is due to be released in April. I intend to use that process for developing a government response to the IC report, which must be done within two months of the report being published. It is not just to look at the issues being raised by the IC report itself, but to use the opportunity to have a look at the statutory arrangements that generally apply in the meat industry around Australia. We will prepare a discussion paper which will provide a basis for an extensive industry consultation process. This process will be managed by the Australian Meat and Live-stock Industry Policy Council, which will bring together the key industry groups to provide a consolidated industry response. I see it as a process of government, ensuring that the fundamental structures and programs are tailored for the future needs of this important industry.

While the immediate market outlook is very sound, there are clear signs that the international meat market will become increasingly competitive, not just from the United States but also from South American producers once their herds achieve disease free status. What we must do—and I am sure that industry and government acting cooperatively will do—is to ensure that we are prepared for competition in the future.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Science and Small Business, in his capacity as the minister responsible for the Australian Customs Service. I refer the minister to his announcement yesterday that Mr Frank Kelly, the former Comptroller-General of the Australian Customs Service, has been appointed as a senior adviser with the Department of Industry, Technology and Regional Development without loss of pay. I ask: given that Mr Kelly and his department have cost the government $25 million in compensation payments, why was Mr Kelly not treated like any other senior employee in a comparable position in the private sector and sacked for incompetence? Is it because the government is running scared about what Mr Kelly might reveal if he were unceremoniously dumped?

—I can dismiss utterly the suggestion that the government is running scared on this issue of reforming Customs. In the 10 months since becoming minister, with government support, I launched the Conroy review with the broadest terms of reference for an inquiry into Customs that has been held in recent history. I have already announced that the broad thrust of the recommendations are acceptable to me, but I will be going to cabinet within six to eight weeks with a considered report and submission on each of the recommendations, many of which are unprecedented in their sweep and demand for change within Customs. I will do so in a considered way so that my own department and, particularly, the Australian Customs Service, the unions and the industry as clients have a chance to put forward their views about these widesweeping recommendations. I say to Senator Ferguson and the Senate that I will do everything possible to make the commitment to get these changes through, to get the culture change involved in Customs.

—Mr President, I rise on a point of order. We have had two minutes of non-answer. The question was not about whether this minister had the courage to set up some sort of inquiry. The question was: why did this minister not sack Mr Kelly for incompetence? I therefore ask you to direct him to answer that part of the question.

—I am astonished by that point of order. The last part of the question specifically asked whether I was running scared and whether I had the courage to sack Mr Kelly. I am answering that part of the question first.

—I cannot possibly be expected to determine from my position how ministers should answer questions. It seemed to me that the minister was to the point in most of what he was saying, and I ask him to try to answer the rest of the question in the time allocated.

—Mr President, I made that commitment yesterday and I make it again today as the minister responsible for Customs. On the position of Mr Kelly: under the existing act, Mr Kelly is a statutory office-holder. He was appointed for seven years and had nearly two years of that appointment left to run. As Senator Ferguson would know, statutory office-holders are appointed under acts of parliament and, unlike a secretary to a department, cannot be removed by administrative decision.

PARA.TAB: After discussion with Mr Kelly, he agreed to stand down from that position but he made the decision—as he was quite entitled to do because he is a permanent public servant of long standing—not to resign from the Public Service. Therefore, when he stood down, whatever position he may or may not have been appointed to by me, he would have been unattached at a senior level of the Public Service, even if we had not given him a job to do. In view of his record—a good record, with Customs being recognised internationally for what it is doing—he would be able to provide good advice about developing international harmonisation rules on customs, particularly in our region.

Mr Kelly's appointment was approved by the Public Service Commissioner, Mr Ives, for a period equivalent to the period he had remaining as Comptroller-General of Customs. When that appointment finishes, he will still be a member of the Australian Public service, with all the rights so entailed. At that time, and in consultation with the Public Service, he will have to make decisions about the job he will have, as all members of the Public Service are entitled to do.

TALK.START.PARA: —At no penalty at all.

—If I had taken action to remove him from the Public Service by administrative decision, those opposite would have been the first to claim that I had acted against the law, acted precipitantly and acted without due process. Whenever the government takes some action to carry out reform, it is criticised by the people opposite. This appointment was made in accordance with the procedures and rules laid down by the Public Service Act, and there is nothing untoward about it. Senator Ferguson may have a blood lust and want to lock horns, but it was all done properly and appropriately in accordance with the position that Mr Kelly holds within the Public Service.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I do not know how the minister can stand there and say that Mr Kelly was competent when the report was as damning an indictment of him as we could have. He did not really answer my question. Since Mr Kelly, as the head of the department, has already cost the government $25 million in compensation, surely, if he did have a seven-year contract, it would not have hurt to pay him out for the last couple of years of it. That would have been a mere drop in the ocean compared with $25 million.

—At times, one can only be astonished at the stupidity of the opposition. If I had announced that Mr Kelly was to be paid out his remaining two years at an equivalent level of salary, those opposite would have abused me for giving him a lump sum payment. This way, paying him the same amount of money, he is still performing a duty in an area where he has played an active and creditable role. If Senator Ferguson reads the Conroy report carefully, he will see that over the years Customs has been given credit for the work it has done in introducing electronic systems to improve efficiency in handling customs procedures and for the role it has played in international fora.

PARA.TAB: Mr Kelly has been asked to serve the equivalent of the two years remaining under his contract as comptroller-general, in an area where he has expertise and where there is not specific and overwhelming criticism from the Conroy review. I accept the criticism about the internal arrangements for Customs in Australia and that is why I have acted the way I have.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Trade. Bearing in mind the process of dramatic economic reform that is taking place in India, can the minister inform the Senate what the government is doing to bolster our bilateral relationships with India? Also, what measures are being taken to encourage greater commercial participation by Australian businesses in the Indian market?

—That is an important question because Australians, particularly those not from the west coast, have underestimated the significance of our Indian Ocean connections. While we have been a little slow to realise our Pacific Ocean possibilities, we have been even slower to realise our Indian Ocean possibilities.

PARA.TAB: One of the welcome opportunities I had as a backbench government senator was to participate with colleagues from all sides of the chamber at the initiation of the Senate review into Australia's relations with India, chaired by former Senator Maguire. The review did an outstanding job in raising people's consciousness of the importance of Australia's relations with India. I welcomed that activity undertaken by government, opposition and minor party senators.

It has been more important in an economic and trade sense in recent times—since mid-1991—because the current Indian government, quite courageously, has made some pretty significant economic reforms. In Australia we all know how difficult it is to make tough political decisions in the area of economic reform. India has made some very substantial changes to a big, hard-to-change economy and it has done so in a period when, initially, it did not even have a majority in the lower house of the parliament. We all know that it is hard enough to operate without one in the upper house, so we can imagine the difficulty it must have had. Through this process, India has reinvigorated its economy and created a wide range of business opportunities in which countries such as Australia can participate.

My predecessor, Senator Cook, initiated an important Indian trade and investment study, the interim results of which look very encouraging. It is a survey both of investment and business opportunities for Australia and of Australian business experience and its perceived problems in doing business with India. It is expected that this report will be released in May.

Against this background the report made a very important contribution to the discussions I had last week with the Indian Minister of State for Commerce, Mr Ahmed, during the Third Australia-India Joint Ministerial Commission. To me, the most encouraging thing about the commission is the very active and broad range of private sector involvement in it—over 70 private sector representatives.

In addition to the formal discussions which took place there was a lot of very animated, active and potentially very productive and profitable dialogue between the private sector representatives both in the working groups and during the dinner and lunch adjournments, et cetera, when, as honourable senators would be aware, the opportunity for that informal contact took place. That augurs well for significant initiatives in Australian-Indian business relationships.

We also made some strong official representations during the course of those discussions, particularly about reduction of tariffs on coal and wool going into India. We are optimistic that we will achieve some favourable response which will be of mutual benefit, gaining us more exports and getting India good inputs into its industrial development process. The minister expressed interest in pursuing that matter further. It is a matter on which our officials will have further discussion and on which I await some interesting responses.

We also raised some positive prospects about Australian company participation in major projects and the possibility of negotiations this year on an investment promotion and protection agreement which Australian business regards as very important. I think Indian business would see that as underpinning the bilateral trade relationship which shows such potential.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Tierney Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories. I draw the minister's attention to the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974 for which Mrs Kelly has responsibility, and particularly to section 5(1) which states inter alia:

QUESTION.PARA: The object of this Act is to ensure . . . that matters affecting the environment to a significant extent are fully examined and taken into account . . . in relation to . . .

PARA.TAB: b)the carrying out of works and other projects; . . .
d)the making of . . . decisions . . . ; and
e)the incurring of expenditure;

QUESTION.PARA: Did Mrs Kelly fulfil her responsibilities under this act when awarding a grant under the sports rorts program of $49,000 to the Eastern Suburbs Cricket Club at Maitland?

TALK.START.PARA: —Quite clearly, no, is the answer to that and, quite clearly, nor should she. I do not know why Senator Tierney has this set against the East Maitland cricket club. As far as I know, there are very fine people in Maitland, participating in a great Australian sport, which I would have thought would have brought joy to their hearts and even to Senator Tierney's heart, if he had one.

PARA.TAB: All I can say is that we have made this grant. Looking at all the things Senator Tierney has brought up about this poor club, I do not know what it did to him. This is a program that works on reimbursement. Therefore, if there is trouble about a site, the club will be able to negotiate, change sites and, in the end, when it has approval from the state government—which is the one that regulates the approval; not the Commonwealth, I hasten to add—then obviously it can proceed to build and get the reimbursement of the $49,000. The Commonwealth does not have the power or the responsibility to make the decision on where the East Maitland cricket club might build a ground. We ought to acknowledge that people in local communities who get together and form cricket clubs so that young people in Australia have useful activities at the weekends ought to be congratulated. I am right behind the East Maitland cricket club. These are great people and Senator Tierney ought to give them a go.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question after that nonsense answer. Obviously I have nothing against cricket clubs. We are against the way the government allocates money without proper guidelines. I ask the minister to answer the question this time and explain, in the light of the environment protection legislation, why that club was allowed to have a grant for a site which was contaminated with toxic tar. The Environmental Protection Agency has ordered that the site be fenced off because it is a public danger. We are talking about the government's procedures, not the outcome.

—I can only repeat that this is a program where payment is made on reimbursement. Therefore, when any club at all, let alone this cricket club—it may be another club that Senator Tierney wishes to pick on—chooses a site, the state government will have the power to make a decision as to whether anything is built on it or not. Once the state government has made a decision that the answer to that is no, then the club will negotiate for another site. When that is approved, we will pay the money, but not until then. Therefore, the Commonwealth's revenue is protected. There is no possibility of the Commonwealth's revenue being in any danger. I again appeal to Senator Tierney to please stop picking on the people of East Maitland.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Regional Development. I, too, refer to the Ford closures, but in the context of the Australian Democrats' strategic tariff and industry policies which stand in contrast to the policies of both the opposition and the government, even though they pretend to fight over minute differences. I ask the minister: is he concerned that the proportion of imported motor vehicles sold in Australia has risen to almost 50 per cent in 1993-94, compared with approximately 33 per cent only five years ago, with a loss in employment of 24 per cent? What steps, if any, is he prepared to take to reverse this trend, and, in particular, would he consider any additional measures to encourage research and product development by the car industry and by industry generally?

—I will take each of those points in reverse order and commence with research and development. I met on Friday morning with the automotive industries of Australia. They put to me some ideas about research and development and product development, which I have before me. I am actively considering them and they will go into any industry statement that I make. On the question of what steps, if any, I am prepared to take in addition to the existing arrangements for the car industry plan, Senator Spindler is probing me about what I might do in the statement. I think the fundamentals of the car industry plan have worked appropriately and well, and I would not want to disturb them. But one always looks at plans such as this to see how better they might be targeted to achieve their goals.

PARA.TAB: On the first point, Senator Spindler has quoted some statistics. They are not relevant in the case of this closure, and I give him statistics of my own. In 1990, the Corolla, which is wholly made in Australia, had 26.7 per cent of the market share. The Laser, which is constructed out of knocked-down packs, had 28 per cent of the market share. Last year the Corolla had 24.2 per cent of the market share, a decline of 2.5 per cent it is admitted. The Laser had 16.6 per cent of the market share, a decline of 11.4 per cent. It is because of that market decline, I think it is fair to say, that the company now finds its production in this form uneconomic and has taken the steps it has.

But what Senator Spindler has neglected to do in the statistics he has quoted to me is refer also to the export performance of this industry. If one takes the export performance of this industry from its inception in 1984 until 1993, one sees that there has been a 225 per cent increase in exports of motor vehicles and car parts from Australia. As I have said, last year there was a 20 per cent increase. It is true that employment has reduced significantly in this industry, but this industry is globally competitive. It has paid a great deal of attention to embracing new technology to put itself at the leading edge of technology and development. It has paid a lot of attention to increasing productivity per head and improving the quality of its product as well, so that Australian produced motor vehicles or car parts are at world quality and productivity levels, and thus competitive. It has largely succeeded in doing that.

What has to be said about major factory-based production line industry in the world—not just Australia—is that there is always a shrinkage of labour with the introduction of new technology. That is typical of every centre in the world where this occurs. It is not surprising that it should show up in our figures as well.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I think the minister should consider that, while our exports have risen, they have risen from a very small base. I think the job losses, despite productivity increases, indicate that we are still not in balance. I wonder whether in his consideration of the industry statement the minister would like to consider that five or six nations in the region have car tariffs ranging from 55 per cent to 300 per cent?

—It is true that it has risen from a small base, but it is now valued at $1.5 billion, which is not insignificant in terms of export earnings for Australia and is a reason why the car plan is turning a positive result. It is one of the reasons that Mitsubishi, Toyota and Holden have made the commitments they have and why I expect Ford will do the same. When we look at the industry statement, and I hope to do this in consort with my colleague Senator McMullan, we will look at the market and questions of market impediment or market obstruction. But we have just completed the GATT round which resulted in across-the-board reductions in tariff protection. There may be a case for looking at some bilateral strategies to deal with that issue. In the broad compass of the industry statement we will methodically, systematically and, I expect, intelligently deal with those issues.

—I address my question to the minister representing the Minister for Communications and the Arts. I refer to the current Australian Federal Police inquiry into Telecom bugging of phone calls from members of the Casualties of Telecom group. Will the minister give me an assurance as a parliamentary representative doing my parliamentary duty for my constituents, which included members of COT, that bugged recordings of my conversations are not held in the room full of tapes as described to Minister Lee by Mr Frank Blount. Further, will the minister give an assurance that from 7 to 15 September 1992 when Telecom has admitted tape recording Mrs Ann Garms's phone, at a time when COT had just been formed and was negotiating with Telecom, or the period up to 23 October up to which date Telecom documentation has now revealed the taping continued, no recordings of phone calls with me are included. Or, finally, does the room full of recorded—(Time expired)

—That part of the question which we did have the opportunity to get in the time essentially relates—and I will come to the specifics of Senator Boswell's question in a moment—to a broad issue which Senator Alston has raised on a couple of occasions. On those occasions I outlined to the Senate the action that is being taken on a number of fronts relating to the alleged monitoring and recording of customer telephone conversations. Those answers outlined a series of inquiries and investigations that have been initiated internally by Telstra, the AFP and Austel.

PARA.TAB: I have made it clear to Senator Alston and I reiterate the generality to Senator Boswell—I will come to what I can say about the specifics in a moment—that while these inquiries are continuing, neither the minister nor certainly I as his representative is going to make any comment on specific matters relating to allegations of recording of customer telephone conversations. That is a matter which, in general, should wait until we get the outcome of those inquiries. TALK.START.PARA: —The exhibition to which Senator Colston refers is entitled `The Children of the Holocaust', an exhibition of drawings by Jewish children of the Terezin ghetto. That exhibition is to be opened by the Prime Minister later this evening. There is a quite simple reason why the Australian War Memorial should stage such an exhibition. I think it does bring into sharp focus the devastating effects of the war in Europe and symbolises the tyranny which Australians fought against during that war. It also acknowledges the strength of the human spirit of those who were affected by the atrocities during the war.

PARA.TAB: This is the first international exhibition staged by the memorial. It consists of drawings done by children in the Terezin ghetto in what is now the Czech republic. It is on loan to the memorial from the State Jewish Museum of Prague. Following its exhibition at the memorial, it will be on show at the Sydney Jewish Museum.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday in question time Senator Panizza asked me a question regarding the impact of the embargo on Iraq on Australian wheat pools. I have an answer for Senator Panizza. PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

ANSWER.PARA: Australia is owed some A$660 million (US$482 million) for wheat sold to Iraq prior to the imposition of United Nations trade sanctions in 1990. The Australian Wheat Board has already been reimbursed some $530 million under their Export Finance and Insurance Corporation (EFIC) national interest insurance policy.
This sharing of the risk, 80% Commonwealth and 20% AWB, reflects the contractual agreement reached for the provision for insurance cover for these sales, under the national interest facility.
The AWB has an exposure to Iraqi debt of some A$130 million (US$97 million) relating to equity in the 1987/88, 1988/89 and the 1989/90 wheat pools. None of this debt has been written off.
Iraq has undertaken to repay all of this debt as soon as it is able to do so. Its ability to repay will depend on when the United Nations decides to lift its sanctions on Iraq.

In addition, the government has paid the grains industry $32.9 million to cover losses on sales of wheat, rice and yellow split peas contracted prior to the imposition of the United Nations trade sanctions on Iraq (in August 1990), and associated costs in re-selling those commodities to alternative markets.

The equity relating to Iraqi debt in the 1987/88 and 1988/89 pools was transferred to the 1990/91 pool at a nominal amount to allow the closure of these pools. The equity relating to Iraqi debt was placed in a separate account. The AWB has advised growers that a record of their entitlements in these pools will be maintained for at least 3 years and any payments from Iraq received during that time will be paid to the growers concerned.

Australian growers are carrying the balance of their exposure to Iraqi debt as equity in the 1989/90 pool worth some A$70 million. The Australian Wheat Board is currently considering the options available to close this pool.

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the Senate that I have received the following letter, dated 9 February 1994, from Senator Short:
