SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:

SPEECH.PARA: The need to condemn the Government for the abject failure, under successive responsible ministers, to administer the Australian Customs Service competently, as demonstrated in the critical review of the report, Turning Point, and the grossly inadequate response of the Minister for Science and Small Business (Senator Schacht) to that review.

The review of the Australian Customs Service entitled Turning Point is one of the greatest, most trenchant condemnations of a government agency ever made in this country, and is therefore one of the greatest, most trenchant condemnations made of any government in this country. Despite what the Minister for Science and Small Business, Senator Schacht, and his colleagues on the other side may believe, ultimate responsibility rests with the minister and the government for failures of policy, or failures of administration—and in the case of the subject of this review, both. This review into the operations of the Australian Customs Service was conducted by a high-level and highly experienced team.

TALK.START.PARA: —Appointed by me.

—I accept that, but the review that has come out is a damning indictment of the Australian Customs Service, but more so—for the reasons I have just mentioned—it is a damning indictment of the responsible minister, Senator Schacht, and his predecessors in the portfolio, Mr Beddall, Mr Jones and, before that, former Senator Button. The report makes various extremely important findings. For example, it states:

SPEECH.PARA: The inward looking nature and insularity of the Customs organisation is a matter of serious concern.

The report calls for the abolition of the Australian Customs Service and the positions of the comptroller-general, his deputies, collectors and all the other senior executive officers. It calls for major rationalisation, large management savings and staff cuts. These are not minor matters by any means. Indeed, they go right to the heart and core of administration. My colleagues Senator Ferguson and Senator Bishop will be elaborating on some of these aspects in their comments during this unfortunately truncated debate. More specifically, the report summarises its views as follows:

Criticism was consistent and wide ranging, from internal policies and practices, such as mobility and training of staff, to claims of intimidation and inconsistency in dealing with companies. There were allegations of inefficiency, secrecy, lack of commercial judgement, poor communication, inflexibility, confusion of purpose, lack of specialist skills, ineffectual leadership and lack of accountability for actions.
Damningly, the committee formed the view:

. . . Customs have lost direction and management are generally unresponsive to industry requirements, adopting defensive attitudes, preferring not to make critical decisions and establishing mechanisms to avoid those decisions.
Those are very serious matters indeed, coming on top of the scandalous requirement for the $25 million payout over the Midford Paramount debacle.

PARA.TAB: There was no reason at all for the minister not to be aware of the problems within the Customs Service, and no excuse for his or his predecessors' failure to act in this regard. Since 1970 there have been no fewer than 20 reports into the Australian Customs Service. There have been three reports since 1990, and major reports into its operations in 1983, 1987, 1990, 1991 and 1992. The 1987 report was that of a task force set up specifically to examine alleged shortcomings in customs legislation and practice. This latest review has found:

SPEECH.PARA: There are clear instances that can be traced back as far as the Mahoney report in 1983 where recommendations accepted by Customs either clearly have not been implemented or where strong doubts exist on sustained implementation action.
Of the reports of the last 20 years or so, there have been some 150 specific recommendations for change and improvement in the Customs Service. Very few, if any, of those have been acted on.

PARA.TAB: I ask the question, to which I hope the minister will respond: why has not the succession of Labor ministers with responsibility for the Customs Service ever done anything about this at all? The matter that concerns me most of all is the question of ministerial responsibility and accountability, because under this government the convention of ministerial responsibility has gone right out the window. It is almost as if the government has never heard of that convention. It does not give a damn about public administration; rather, it practises maladministration.

The government rorts the political system, as we have seen in recent weeks par excellence with minister Kelly, who has not got the decency, or any concept of accountability, to resign. We have seen the problem with Minister Griffiths, who has resigned. We saw the problem in earlier years with Mick Young. In fact, he had to resign three times. We saw the misleading of the parliament by John Brown, who also had to resign. In all of those cases, those resignations were dragged out of the ministers of the day, who went down screaming, without any willingness to accept their ministerial responsibility.

Under our parliamentary system and traditions, responsibility for the administration of a minister's department rests fairly and squarely with the minister—in this case, of course, the subject of today's debate, Senator Schacht. It is alarming in the extreme to find the inadequate, half-hearted response that the minister has given. All Senator Schacht has done is give the report to DITARD to investigate. He obviously had no alternative but to ask Mr Frank Kelly to resign—and Mr Kelly had no option, either. I will not go into that at the moment, other than to say it is quite extraordinary that a person who presided in the administrative sense over the activities which were the subject of such brutal criticism by this review committee should have now been appointed as a very senior departmental adviser earning no less than $126,000 a year. That can only be described as sending absolutely the wrong signal. I ask Senator Schacht whether he can tell me in his response if that appointment is for two years or longer and, if so, for what term.

There are many additional things I would like to say but time prevents that. I conclude my remarks by saying that at the end of the day the buck stops with the minister and with the government. The government has known for many years that things were sadly wrong within the Australian Customs Service, its operations and practices. It is a disgrace that nothing has been done, requiring this review to highlight these matters. Although our urgency motion today does not call for it, if the minister had any sense of his own responsibility he would have no option but to resign.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Science and Small Business and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —What an astonishing performance from Senator Short. I commissioned the review; I gave it its terms of reference; I appointed the people and the secretariat to the review and told them to get on with the job without inhibition, with those very broad terms of reference. I knew full well there were many complaints in the community as well as in this parliament about the performance of the Australian Customs Service; that, in the aftermath of the Midford affair, there would be plenty of trenchant criticism made in submissions to that review and that, on the balance of probabilities, the review would make recommendations that would be very critical of the performance of the Customs Service.

PARA.TAB: Senator Short can ask me to resign as a political stunt on any number of occasions, but it is a bit rich, the day after the tabling of the report I commissioned almost in the first month and a half of being minister, that he then asks me to resign because I commissioned a report that has been critical.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have been in charge of the administration of this department for almost a year.

—Yes, and during that period I thought the best way to get a considered position was to have an independent review of the whole structure, knowing full well that there was widespread criticism in this parliament and in the community. That is the considered and sensible way to proceed.

PARA.TAB: I can imagine what would have happened if I had started moving into Customs by lopping a head here and there—which is what those opposite would have wanted to do—and changing structures off my own bat. I would have been criticised in this chamber of taking precipitative action with no considered review. That would have been the criticism. Those opposite would then have been asking me to resign because I had acted impulsively and precipitantly.

I have gone about this in the proper way. A considered report is now before the parliament and before the people of Australia about the future of Customs. It makes it very clear that Customs has to change substantially—not just in its administration, not just in its application of rules, but also in its culture. It will only change if we get direction from the bottom up as well as from the top down. If we make the thousands of individual Customs employees willing to support the significant cultural change that they and their service have to go through, we will get the sort of long-term reform within the organisation that would prevent a disaster such as Midford happening again. No-one on the government side enjoyed having to make a decision to pay out $25 million in compensation. We could all think of a hundred other areas in which we would rather spend $25 million than compensation. But, since I have been minister, it has been my first and long-term aim to bring about change in Customs.

I have said that I support the general thrust of the report before the government. I have not committed myself to any individual recommendation. It would be unwise for me to do so before I get a considered proposal to cabinet because the recommendations have been described in some quarters as unprecedented in any Commonwealth government department. The report talks about a possible 1,400 redundancies out of a total of 4,800 positions. It talks about changing the act to wipe out the statutory offices of the comptroller-general and deputy comptrollers-general. It wipes out the Australian Customs Service. It recommends the creation of an organisation called Customs Australia and the appointment of a chief executive. It recommends the abolition of the present structure, with many individual programs to be reorganised into three separate programs with a chief executive in charge. They represent substantial and significant structural changes, yet those opposite expect me to get the report one day, table it in parliament and immediately announce the changes. If we go that way, we will not get the change at the grassroots level of the system, down among the serving officers. That is the most important change we need to make. We can restructure the pyramid with a flat new management structure or whatever, but unless we get a culture change among the serving officers, problems such as Midford will keep coming up. The culture has to change from within.

That is the message I want to drive home with this report. From the brief discussions I have already had with senior management and from addressing over 350 middle level and senior staff yesterday at Customs here in Canberra, I think there is an overwhelming predisposition amongst the ordinary staff to adopt the change and get on with the job in a constructive way. Many of those people want the change because they know their service, their department, is being affected in its standing in the community by such disasters as Midford. They want to make the change, and we intend to support them by making it in a cooperative way. Certainly, the opposition can swing the axe and abuse people up hill and down dale, but that does not get culture change—and culture change is what I am committed to.

I know Senator Short has had no ministerial experience—it may be a long time before he gets the opportunity—but the way to go in executive government in relation to this issue is to take the recommendations and get the support of cabinet to make these changes. After a period, when Customs has had the opportunity to comment, I believe Customs will overwhelmingly accept the recommendations. Other departments may also have a view, the union may have a view, and clients of Customs in the community may wish to comment on them. I received information today from various clients of Customs commenting on the report. Most of it is constructive and positive. The proper way to go is to give those people and organisations an opportunity to contribute constructively to this reorganisation of Customs.

The issue that most people have got themselves into a lather about is, of course, Mr Kelly. Mr Kelly has resigned as comptroller-general. He is a statutory office-holder, and he will be until Friday when the resignation takes effect. That gives him, because the parliament has given them to him, certain rights regarding his own position.

After discussion, Mr Kelly agreed to stand down from that position, but he had every right to stay in the Public Service, which he has. He has every right, as I said in an answer today to Senator Ferguson, to keep those privileges as a member of the Public Service, and he has. In my view, he has particular skills in the international area, where Customs has played a prominent role, and he will be an adviser to the government in that area over the next 20 months—the remainder of what would have been his period—

TALK.START.PARA: —What about after that?

—Senator Ferguson should let me finish. That would have been his remaining period as Comptroller-General of Customs. After that, if he does not resign from the Public Service, he will continue on the unattached list.
—How long do you think he would last in the private sector?

—Those are the rules of the Public Service, established under an act of this parliament. So he has the right to stay there. I imagine that in 20 months time, or when that period expires, he will make a judgment about whether he wants to stay in the Public Service and what his opportunities are. That is his individual choice and he has every right to make it. I do not think people opposite should get too carried away about the fact that Mr Kelly has gone to this position. He would have been entitled to be paid a substantial amount of money on the unattached list.

PARA.TAB: The appointment of Mr Chris Doogan as acting comptroller-general has also been criticised.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have not criticised that.

—Some people have made that criticism. I have explained to him, and I have said it publicly, that he will be there as acting comptroller-general until the government considers what structure it wants for Customs and makes a decision as to the chief executive. He will be eligible to apply for the position as will anybody else in the public sector, as well as people from outside. He understands that. But in the meantime, as acting comptroller-general, he will get on with the job of responding to me about the Conroy report.

PARA.TAB: In the immediate future, as we prepare for the cabinet submission, I will be looking at the recommendation for the establishment of an advisory council of people with expertise from outside Customs to advise the minister in this process of change. That is a recommendation I am very sympathetic to, and I hope to be able to act on that in the very near future.

I assure honourable senators opposite that I am committed to being, and I accept ministerial responsibility for being, the minister for Customs. I am committed to getting change in Customs, but the change will not occur just because I, as minister, decree from the top down; it will ultimately occur effectively for the long term if we get people within Customs to understand the need for change. That is what I am committed to, and I will get on with that job.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to contribute to this matter of urgency debate. The motion says:

SPEECH.PARA: The need to condemn the Government for the abject failure under successive responsible Ministers to administer the Australian Customs Service competently,—

The Australian Democrats support this urgency motion with one proviso. While it is certainly clear that the government deserves censure over its failure on a long range basis to administer this department and control it competently, I believe it is difficult to say that the response of Senator Schacht, the current minister, to this report has been grossly inadequate. I find that his response has been adequate. Not only has he started this inquiry, but also he has undertaken to implement it in broad terms and to assess each detail. I find it difficult to say that his performance is grossly inadequate.

PARA.TAB: Nevertheless, I believe it is appropriate that we support the censure motion as it stands with that proviso because the record is on the board. The executive summary of the report states:

SPEECH.PARA: There were allegations of inefficiency, secrecy, lack of commercial judgment, poor communication, inflexibility, confusion of purpose, lack of specialist skills, ineffectual leadership and lack of accountability for actions.

One really could not have much more than that. This excellent report is now on the table and these deficiencies are clearly itemised. I take this opportunity to pay tribute to the panel: the Chairman, former Westpac chief, Mr Frank Conroy; Mr Ian Macphee, a former Liberal minister; and Ms Susan Ryan, a former Labor minister. I believe this report can stand as a model of investigation and reporting for similar reports, and no doubt—the minister might agree, somewhat wryly perhaps—other government departments could do with a report of this nature. The minister has acknowledged the serious deficiencies in management. It is worth noting that the deficiencies include hierarchical structure and no direction, and in many parts of our public administration these are areas that we should address.

PARA.TAB: Rather than reiterating these facts—and the report is a weighty one—and taking up the time of this chamber, I believe the time and energy of this house would be better applied to the commitment to ensure that the responses that the government makes are appropriate, and that the recommendations are carried out to the extent that that is appropriate.

I would like to lift out one particular recommendation which gives me unadulterated pleasure. It says that there should be no duty-free tobacco products. In terms of the whole report that is a marginal issue, but in terms of the benefits that could be derived from that recommendation for the health of individual citizens and the costs of the health system, it is one that is worth mentioning.
I will turn to the area that continues to give me great concern, and that is the anti-dumping section.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would be surprised if you didn't, Sid.
—I am sure the minister is not surprised that I am doing it. The mission statement says:

SPEECH.PARA: To support Australia's economic and social development through:—
and the first item says—

PARA.TAB: fulfilment of industry assistance objectives.

SPEECH.PARA: I have some difficulty with the way in which the particular area of industry assistance in which I am specifically interested—the anti-dumping provisions—is being dealt with, because I believe it is very faulty. On page 166, paragraph 15.43, the report says:

PARA.TAB: Anti-dumping and countervailing are not ethical matters.

SPEECH.PARA: That is a very important statement. We are not obliged to treat other nations in the way in which they would want; there is no moral obligation to do that when we are protecting our interests. We are dealing with attacks on the life blood of our industries and on the employment of Australians. The report says:

PARA.TAB: The complexity of commercial behaviour and systems deny simple explanations and remedies to claims made to the Committee that anti-dumping law should be administered with an approach favouring Australian producers.

SPEECH.PARA: I know there were many submissions and witnesses. I made a submission and appeared as a witness. I unashamedly say to the customs department that one of its duties is to protect Australian industries when they are under attack by cheap imports being dumped into our economy.

PARA.TAB: We are told in paragraph 15.45 that it is difficult to deal with that because, occasionally, dumped products assist our industries through their absorption into Australian produced products. I think that argument is irrelevant. So what! Good luck to those industries. If Australian employers and workers are not harmed by dumping but, on the contrary, are assisted, good luck to them. Why worry? Why would that, in any way, affect the obligation of Customs and the minister to ensure that no harm comes to Australian industries? Paragraph 15.46 states:
A telling aspect of this issue lies in the position of Customs as the middle player perennially the centre of attack.

SPEECH.PARA: So what! Stiff! Customs' job is to protect Australian industries. If the Customs Service is in the middle, if it is being fired upon from all sides, it is still its job to be competent and to make sure that it does its job in accordance with its mission statement. Paragraph 15.47 states:

PARA.TAB: If Customs is, therefore, to service local industry's needs better in relation to dumping matters, the Committee believes it should be as an adviser and educator to all on dumping practice and procedure,—

SPEECH.PARA: so far so good—
not as an advocate or technical adviser to any section of Australian industry.
Not to any section of Australian industry but to an industry or part of an industry that is under attack from cheap imports being dumped on our markets.

PARA.TAB: In this area, the Customs Service is paid to protect the principle of fair competition; to ensure that our industries are not attacked by unfair competition caused by products being dumped on Australian markets at below cost. I will not repeat what I said yesterday when I commented on the minister's answer to a question on various suggested measures, such as shortening the period during which an anti-dumping claim can be dealt with and providing a clear indication of procedures such as revising the laws to make them clearer.
It is important that the culture of the Australian Customs Service be changed in line with its mission statement. I will be very carefully assessing what the minister does on this point.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support Senator Short's motion condemning the failure of the Minister for Science and Small Business (Senator Schacht) and successive ministers to administer competently the Australian Customs Service, as demonstrated in the Conroy report, and the failure of Senator Schacht to respond adequately to the report. `Debate' is hardly the right word to describe what is happening because there really is no debate—the Conroy report released yesterday by the minister shows that there is not much room for that.

PARA.TAB: However, interestingly, earlier in question time the minister kept telling the Senate about Mr Kelly's decision to stand down as comptroller-general, as though it was up to Mr Kelly, and not the minister, to take these decisions. Does this mean that public servants who are found wanting can choose whether to resign or to continue in the positions which they handle most incompetently?

TALK.START.PARA: —He was a statutory office holder.

—I understand that. So a statutory office holder who is doing the job as incompetently as this man was is allowed to continue in the job and the effect of his administration of his department is unabated?
—The only way to sack a statutory office holder is by resolution of both houses of parliament.

—So it does not matter how bad or incompetent they are, they are allowed to continue. The minister said that Mr Kelly has every right to stay in the Public Service. I wonder why he has that right. Is it so that he can make more poor decisions in another government position and cause another Midford?
—But he is a permanent public servant.

—Being responsible for such scandals, I would have thought he would have forfeited that right, particularly in light of the Midford Paramount case. After the efforts that Mr Kelly has put in over the past few months, I am surprised that the minister would say that it is Mr Kelly's decision to resign.
—I also said I had discussions with him.

—I understand that the minister had discussions with him, but the minister said that it was Mr Kelly's decision to resign. It does not seem to matter to whom one talks—Australian exporters, importers, customs agents, passengers at our airports, or even farmers who are trying to get diesel fuel rebates—nearly everybody has a story to tell about how they were intimidated or made to feel like a crook or an idiot by the Customs Service.

PARA.TAB: Sometimes that also applies to senators, such as myself, who have tried to get information out of the Customs Service in Senate estimates committees. This has not been an easy task and as a result, as the minister would be well aware, there are now two matters before the privileges committee, which is investigating whether Customs Service officers have misled or failed to provide relevant information to estimates committees. One of these privilege matters relates to Midford Paramount and the other—the minister is well aware that I have been involved in this matter—relates to the diesel fuel rebate scheme.

I only mention these matters because it appears to me that the attitude of the Customs Service—not only towards the public, but also towards the institution of parliament and its own minister—is somewhat disrespectful, to say the least. After the Midford Paramount case, the damning report by the Joint Committee on Public Accounts and the referral of the Midford Paramount matter to the privileges committee, I would have thought that the Australian Customs Service had been put on notice well and truly and would be willing to mend its ways. But no, it jumped, boots and all, into the diesel fuel rebate debacle, stranding the minister like a shag on a rock. Perhaps a more appropriate analogy would be that of the Customs Service hanging like an albatross around the minister's neck, although the science community would probably compete for that.

I do not know whether the minister knows this, but the talk is that the Customs Service has tried to `mushroom' him—keep him in the dark. I do not know what the minister could have done to deserve this—I have no idea—but it would go a long way towards explaining some events. If this were the case—if the service deliberately decided not to cooperate with its new minister and to let him hang at estimates—it would be consistent with the view that the Customs Service is a law unto itself.

If this mushrooming has occurred, it is an outrageous attack on our system of government. Public servants are just that—servants of the public. They do not decide, regardless of what the people want and what the people's representatives want, that they will be a law unto themselves and ignore their minister. I would also be unspeakably outraged if a minister who was aware that he was being mushroomed failed to act and failed to sack the relevant officers or did not take some definitive action to stamp his authority on the department.

I cannot begin to speculate why this minister and Customs ministers before him have let the Australian Customs Service run rampant. I do not know if this minister or previous ministers have tried to bring the service into line and failed. I do not know if the Customs Service has managed to convince this minister and previous ministers that it was changing and that it was adopting the recommendations of the previous reports on it. There have been plenty of reports and recommendations, yet this minister had to commission another one. I hope he has read the other reports because there were plenty of recommendations for changes to be made.

Eventually the Midford Paramount case became the customs equivalent of the Royal Australian Navy's sexual harassment case on the HMAS Swan. Like the HMAS Swan, Midford Paramount is probably only the tip of the iceberg. Anyone who thinks that the sexual harassment was an isolated incident or thinks that a management shake-up in the Customs Service will suffice is walking around in a fantasy world. As the minister has already mentioned, there needs to be a culture change in the Customs Service and it needs to be calculated and swift because we do not want the patient to die while waiting for a blood transfusion.

I am disappointed that the minister has not made that immediate commitment, but has talked instead about evaluating the recommendations, taking a submission to cabinet in six or eight weeks and generally following the usual slow channels. At this rate it could be a long time before any substantial action is taken. I wait with bated breath to see what the minister's recommendations will be. I believe that this minister and previous ministers should have smelt a rat a long time ago.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hang on! I think I did.
—Maybe the minister did, but it has taken a while. Instead things have been allowed to progress so far—
—I announced this review in May last year, after only a month in the job.

—I understand that, but there were plenty of other reviews to look at. If things were so rotten in the Customs Service, why has the minister sat on his hands and let things keep going? He had a review, yet things were still happening during that time. Why did the minister allow the man at the helm and the man responsible for the day-to-day running of the Australian Customs Service to sit on his hands for the past five years, and now that the game is up, be rewarded with a senior adviser's position? I think it is a joke and makes a mockery of our Westminster system of government. Ministers are expected to be accountable and to resign if there is maladministration. People in positions such as Mr Kelly's should do the same and not be rewarded with other jobs.

PARA.TAB: The public also expects that public servants in senior positions will be treated in the same way their private sector counterparts could expect to be treated. If circumstances warrant it, I do not see any reason why people in the public service should not be sacked for incompetence. I find it totally repugnant that Mr Kelly in his position oversaw the destruction of Midford Paramount which resulted in job losses, ruined reputations and the eventual payment of $25 million in compensation, yet was rewarded with a well-paid soft landing.

I cannot imagine that the minister would like to face up to the 1,400 people whom the Conroy report recommends be made redundant and explain why they have to go, when all the top bananas—particularly the former Comptroller-General—will not suffer at all.

TALK.START.PARA: —He has lost his job.

—He resigned. Is this the message that we want to send to the public? Is this the message we want to send to our children, that it is all right for ministers and public servants to oversee the ruination of peoples' lives and not be accountable? Obviously, the answer is no, and that is why Senator Schacht must act immediately on this report and make sure that the recommendations come down. It is within his power to act to save the Customs Service from itself and to reassert his authority over this department. The minister must act now, save his credibility and restore the confidence of the public in the Customs Service, in the Public Service generally, and possibly in himself.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carr Sen K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to oppose the resolution. I think it is flawed in a number of ways. Firstly, it refers to the failure of successive responsible ministers to administer the Australian Customs Service. Senator Ferguson indicated in his press release that there have been some 20 reviews of the Customs Service over a period since 1970. Of course, honourable senators would appreciate that the proposition involves acknowledging responsibility back to the period when the Fraser government was in office.

PARA.TAB: In fact, if we look at the Midford Paramount case, the origin of that whole matter arose from discussions between the then Prime Minister, Mr Fraser, and that particular company in regard to the multifibre agreement and the special concessions that were given to that company in relation to their dealings with Malaysia. It is quite clear that the Customs Service behaved incorrectly. It is quite clear that it was obviously annoyed at the special treatment and concessions that Midford Paramount had been given by the Fraser government. When Senator Ferguson talks about successive ministers not being able to deal correctly with this problem, we also have to look at the opposition's history in this matter.

Finally, Senator Ferguson points to what he regards as the inadequate response of this minister to this issue. In this case, I believe that this minister has put a very good case. He is acknowledging that there are problems with the operations and structures of the Australian Customs Service. These problems go back a long way—back to the Fraser government—and have been responded to by this government in a number of substantive ways.

TALK.START.PARA: —You might regret this speech.

—I am glad that Senator Bishop is in the chamber and has interjected in the way that she has, because we will get to her role in this matter very shortly. We have to accept that changes have been instituted by this government and that the government has accepted the majority of the recommendations that arose out of the report of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts.

PARA.TAB: Of course, the bulk of the work undertaken by that committee was done by its Labor members. They did not grandstand or pull the publicity stunts that we see day in and day out from others in an attempt to intimidate and interrogate public servants who cannot defend themselves. Of course, that is not the sort of impression that Senator Bishop wants to give here.

The government has initiated a major review of the operation of the Australian Customs Service chaired by Frank Conroy. This minister instituted that. For Senator Ferguson to talk about the inadequate response of this minister is totally inappropriate. It is a response of a minister to a report that he initiated.

Senator Schacht indicated that he is prepared to accept the thrust of the 106 recommendations from the Conroy report. Naturally, some of those recommendations go to very sensitive matters, and the removal of 1,400 people, I believe, is a very sensitive matter. I, too, will be looking very closely at the way in which Senator Schacht deals with that particular issue.

The government is committed to cultural change within the agency. Senator Schacht has indicated that again and again. The question is the manner by which that change is achieved. That is what is at stake today. The idea of moving in and sacking people, and ruthlessly and aggressively trying to destroy the lives of people, is not the way to proceed.

Senator Bishop indicated before, by way of interjection, that if we find a statutory officer we do not like and want to get rid of—but cannot under the law—we abolish the position. That is the experience in Victoria. We do not then have to face up to any legitimate rights of any individual. That is the policy Senator Bishop talks about.

It is probably appropriate to mention Senator Bishop. Senator Bishop has taken a very high profile on this issue. She has made a great play of it. Once again she has upstaged her shadow ministerial colleague. She has marched in, burst onto the stage and grabbed the limelight. Good on Senator Bishop, well done! All I can say from the Labor Party point of view is, `Thank God for Senator Bishop. She is doing a fantastic job'.

Senator Bishop had been asked to participate in the Conroy inquiry. Did she? No she did not. Senator Bishop had a chat in an airport lounge somewhere on her many trips around to gather a few numbers. Did she put in a submission? No, she did not. Did Senator Bishop in anyway take a constructive, considered and substantive view of the policy questions involved? No. What did you do? You took the cheap shot—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Carr, could you address your remarks through the Chair?

—Yes, I will. Through you, Mr Deputy President, I ask the question: is it possible to know what the views of Senator Bishop are? None of us do. I look forward to hearing them today. What are Senator Bishop's policy positions? Senator Vanstone indicated on the radio in Adelaide just this week her concern—shared by many on this side of the house. She said, `Of course I have not had the opportunity to hear many of Bronwyn's views on substantive matters.' I think Steele Hall is a very lucky man if gets to know a range of her substantive views. Most other people would dearly like to know what they are. From what I have heard and what has been said, my guess is that Senator Bishop is much more conservative than Dr Hewson. We have had a long decade—

—I take a point of order, Mr Deputy President. I have listened to what Senator Carr has to say. While he sticks to the subject I will remain silent, but when he is irrelevant—under standing order 194, he is being irrelevant—I ask that you to bring him back to the matter at hand.

—Matters of public importance invariably and historically do allow for some flexibility, but it would be helpful, Senator Carr, if you would focus your mind on the matters. The other thing, I will say while the point of order is being taken, is that naming senators informally in text is out of order. You are required to use the same description of them as you would if you were addressing them in the chamber.

—Senator Bishop has some problems on this issue, as we have indicated. We are waiting for her substantive views on these questions. We are waiting to hear what official contact she had with the review committee. We are waiting to hear whether or not she participated in the formulation of the matters that are before the Senate here today. All we have seen is the grandstanding nonsense we saw yesterday.

PARA.TAB: I draw the Senate's attention to the real problem the Liberal Party faces in terms of the approach it has taken on its front bench. Geoff Prosser is quoted in today's Australian Financial Review. He says:

SPEECH.PARA: So long as Senator Bishop does not make comments too deeply on issues in the report, I would not have—

TALK.START.PARA: —I take a point of order, Mr Deputy President. I ask that this senator address Mr Prosser with his proper title.
—I did make the point before. When you are quoting, Senator Carr, please add the formal title.
—Mr Prosser said:

SPEECH.PARA: So long as Senator Bishop does not make comments too deeply on issues in the report, I would not have a lot of problems with her. But I will be making the coalition's response to the report.

That is going to be a very interesting problem for Senator Bishop, and for the Liberal Party, to be able to work out a mechanism by which she can offer her substantive opinions on a substantive policy matter other than the sort of hysterical nonsense that we have seen so far.

PARA.TAB: We say that there is a need for substantial reform—a need for cultural change. But we do not throw the baby out with the bath water. The Customs Service is of enormous importance to this country. It collects some $15 billion worth of revenue. It has responsibility for the protection of Australian borders. Some 10 million people a year cross those borders. It has responsibility for assistance with a whole range of industry programs. It is an important agency to these people. It has a responsibility for a range of matters, which this government takes very seriously. A ham fisted, bloody-minded approach is no way to deal with this sort of matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —Poor old Senator Carr was put into this debate with no substance and no policy initiatives. To quote Senator Gareth Evans's favourite words, `he just did a little fulminating'. This motion is in part that we `condemn the Government for the abject failure under successive responsible Ministers'.

PARA.TAB: I am sorry that Senator Button is not here for this debate. I am going to remind the chamber what Senator Button had to say when I moved the motion for the reference of this matter to the Joint Committee of Public Accounts. It is to the credit of Senator Spindler that I took the matter to him, and the Democrats agreed with me that the reference needed to be made. We had spent some 60 hours in estimates asking questions. Any read of the estimates Hansard will show the quality of answers that Mr Kelly failed to give—that is the real description. There was a constant failure to be able to come to grips with policy initiatives or seriously answer a question in a way that was even, straightforward and honest. Again and again we came against these problems. So when I took it to the Democrats to discuss the matter, they agreed that it needed to be referred.

What did Senator Button have to say? He said of me and of the questions I had been asking that I had, `reiterated all sorts of unsubstantiated allegations and it was a tale full of sound and fury, signifying nothing'. That is a bit like Senator Carr's ramblings. He said I had taken $200,000 worth of public servants' time dealing with unsubstantiated allegations'.

Those unsubstantiated allegations turned out to be the federal government using taxpayers money to pay $25 million worth of compensation to people whose lives, reputations and businesses had been destroyed. Does that sound like unsubstantiated allegations? Does that sound like something which did not have any substance? I was not pursuing a policy, Senator Carr.

Senator Button went on to say about me, `It is no good coming in here with her student law moot rhetoric, making further unsubstantiated allegations in the course of this matter'. He then went on to move an amendment to the motion to say, `that Senator Bishop not participate in any hearing of the Committee on the . . . matter of this reference'. He was forced to withdraw that after Senator Harradine, Senator Hill and the Democrats spoke in such a way that he felt humiliated, and withdrew.

He went on to say through this inquiry that he and the government opposed its taking place at all. We had to postpone the hearings for two years because the DPP came and told us that if we called witnesses, he was going to depend on those same witnesses in another prosecution and he did not want them discredited. We agreed not to hear those witnesses before the case. To my dying day I will regret that, because someone was convicted on the evidence of two of those witnesses who came before our committee and were totally discredited.
In the executive summary of the Midford report of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, we see the following passage:

SPEECH.PARA: The committee discovered serious shortcomings, however, in the investigatory work undertaken by the Australian Customs Service in relation to these other matters and concluded that they may well have suffered the same fate as the quota matter if they too had progressed to court proceedings.
In other words, Midford was not isolated. We went on to say:
The committee recognises,—
this is very important—

however, that the Comptroller-General cannot be held personally responsible for all of the actions of his individual subordinate officers. Nevertheless, he must accept responsibility for the overall lack of efficiency and effectiveness of the performance of the ACS, the prevailing culture in the Service and the changes that must be made.

Again and again the Customs Service would say, `We got it right. The courts got it wrong. The hearings got it wrong. Everybody in the world is wrong except the Australian Customs Service.' This is the same attitude that we see in Mr Kelly presumably saying to Senator Schacht, `I will resign but you have got to give me a golden parachute'. Quite clearly, the Conroy committee knew, in this very good and sensible report, the difficulties of getting rid of a statutory officer and therefore it came up with a very sensible recommendation that the Australian Customs Service be abolished, together with all the positions held.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is an excellent report.
—It is an excellent report. The report states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Customs Service be abolished and the following positions also be abolished:
Comptroller-General; Deputy Comptrollers-General; Collectors and all other Senior Executive Service positions.
The Conroy committee knew the difficulty of sacking a statutory officer, so recommended a way in which it could effectively be done.

PARA.TAB: Senator Schacht said here today that he wanted the culture to change from the bottom up and that it was not something that could be achieved top down. I agree with Senator Schacht because that is quite right. But how on earth does he say to those other people in the service that he wants their culture to change when he rewards the very man who was responsible for the oversight of the Australian Customs Service.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not reward him at all, Senator Bishop.

—That is the whole point. The minister has rewarded incompetence. Let us look at what happened to other people where there have been changes. The way it has occurred by way of precedent, where there was a determination to get rid of someone who was incompetent and not worth the taxpayers' money, was to abolish the position; they then seek to reapply and fail. That is the way it is done and he would not be rewarded. The minister has set a precedent. I suspect he felt that he would be seen as smart by getting rid of the person concerned before cabinet accepted the recommendations of the report. That is clearly a mistake on the part of Senator Schacht. He has ruined the good work he had embarked upon.

PARA.TAB: I said in good faith to Senator Schacht when he appointed the inquiry that I was willing to cooperate with it at all times—and I did and had a letter from Senator Schacht.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was more like a bucket of poison.
—Senator Schacht is casting aspersions that are quite unwarranted on the members of the committee or their reporting of the fact that they did in fact consult with me—and that did in fact take place.
—Did you put in a written submission?

—I said in good faith that I would consult with the committee, and I did. I was pleased to see the acknowledgment there and I was delighted to see the outcome of the report which is in line with the Public Accounts Committee report. I have said that the two documents, one containing 134 recommendations, together with this first class report, make a blueprint for the way ahead. I will simply say that by rewarding a man who presided over the demise of the Australian Customs Service sends the wrong signals. That is why I support my colleague Senator Short's motion.

—Senator Short's motion says there is a need to condemn the government for its abject failure under successive responsible ministers to administer the Australian Customs Service competently as demonstrated in the critical review of the report entitled The Turning Point. I think it is very important that this review is so entitled. The report arose out of a process initiated by the Minister for Science and Small Business (Senator Schacht) and by the government, and it does make some criticism with respect to previous reports and the lack of implementation of previous reviews.

PARA.TAB: Indeed, Senator Ferguson made the point that from 1970 onwards there have been a number of reports and indeed there have been. It needs to be reiterated that for the majority of that period until 1983 conservative governments held office and did nothing. The minister has said quite clearly that the government will act on the report's recommendations. But there is a process that has to be followed. I do not make out that I have read the report or indeed know all of the problems or all of the solutions, but certainly one sees from the executive summary a process set down where there needs to be some immediate action. I think what the minister has said and what course of action the government will take are totally in line with this report.

One cannot with the stroke of a pen or by way of immediate decision wipe 1,400 jobs off the employment of people in the public sector. That would be a stupid thing to do. It would not necessarily end up with the best result for finally putting in place a Customs Service that will serve this country's best interests.

As I understand the report, it proposes a range of consultations between industry and people involved with the government to ensure that we do get this right. This report is not necessarily the conclusive end result or indeed it may not contain all of the best in putting in place a future Customs Service.
I would like to take up the point made by Senator Bishop about the sort of Customs Service this country should have.

TALK.START.PARA: —Read the report. You will see it spelt out there.

—It is a funny thing that Senator Bishop's colleagues do not seem to know what her position is, as they are publicly stating. They are all in waiting to hear the big announcement. She may well do that sometime after 26 March, but she may not get the opportunity. The opposition often comes in here criticising the government's policies with respect to the implementation of programs. We have certainly never yet heard anything—in particular from Senator Bishop—about the opposition's policies.

PARA.TAB: We have this report before this chamber and that the government has responded to it in a very positive way. The minister has indicated clearly that we will be seeking to implement the broad thrust of this report. We should be congratulated not only for initiating it but also for doing something about it.(Time expired)
Question put:
That the motion (Senator Short's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Troeth Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a personal explanation.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I table the report of the Australian Parliamentary Delegation to the 89th conference of the Inter-Parliamentary Union held in New Delhi, India, between 12 and 17 April 1993. As leader of the delegation of the 89th Inter-Parliamentary Conference held in New Delhi, it is my pleasure to report to the parliament on the principal outcomes of the conference and its related meetings. At an early stage in the proceedings, delegates considered a possible topic for inclusion in the conference agenda as the supplementary item. After deliberation, the conference voted to debate the situation in the former Yugoslavia. In resolving to pursue this course, the persuasive factors for delegates were the severe and extensive abuse of human rights which was occurring, the violence of the conflict, and the recognition of the need for increased efforts by the international community for the carnage to be stopped. The emphasis of the topic was:

SPEECH.PARA: The need for urgent action in the former Yugoslavia, particularly as regards the protection of minorities and the prevention of further loss of life in order that peaceful co-existence and respect for human rights can be restored for all peoples.

As we have recently learned, the situation in the former Yugoslavia has descended to new depths of horror. In light of the appalling massacre in Sarajevo last weekend, particular urgency has been added to the conference resolution which condemned, in the strongest terms, atrocities against minorities, women and children, and the practice of ethnic cleansing.

PARA.TAB: The conference also expressed deep concern at the escalation of violence, aggression and occupation of territories, particularly in Bosnia-Herzegovina. The resolution emphasised that the international community should seek a solution which does not reward aggression and urge national parliaments and governments to take all necessary measures to protect human rights, implement humanitarian law, promote peace and achieve a lasting solution to the underlying causes of conflict in the former Yugoslavia. The full text of the resolution is included in the report.

An important consideration during debate on the situation in the former Yugoslavia was the need for more effective implementation of the United Nations total arms embargo on all sides as a means of ending continuing aggression in the area. A related issue, arms control, was also considered during the conference from the perspective of `transparency in arms transfers through a global arms register, notably as a means to check the growing use of violence to achieve political objectives'.

The resolution on this topic noted that the keynote of the evolving new world order must be understanding and detente and that the growing interdependence between states can be strengthened only by fraternity and conciliation. The conference called on governments to cooperate fully in the establishment of the register of arms transfers. It also called on members of parliament to bring pressure to bear on their respective governments to participate actively in the maintenance of the register and to promote acceptance for the concept of openness and transparency in the field of military activity.

The second subject item of the conference was one in which I took great personal interest, and it concerned `the implementation of educational and cultural policies designed to foster greater respect for democratic values'.

SPEECH.PARA: The wording of the topic implied that democracy is the preferred, if not the best, form of government, and in that context I recall the words of Sir Winston Churchill who remarked that democracy is `the worst form of government, except for all those other forms that have been tried from time to time'.

PARA.TAB: In my view, it is incumbent on all those who embrace democratic ideals to ensure that democracy survives. The implementation of educational and cultural policies which help to foster greater respect for democratic values is therefore vital to all nations. I commented during the plenary consideration of this topic that Australia has adopted what has proved to be a satisfactory method of achieving this aim, achieving as it does a school-based approach of broad citizenship education with specific programs—most particularly those conducted by the Parliamentary Education Office and the Australian Electoral Commission.

The resolution on this topic detailed in the report recognised that education is a prerequisite for the acceptance and further development of democratic values in a process involving the participation of all citizens, and that cultural interaction can make an important contribution to international understanding and cooperation. It was emphasised that educational and cultural activities must be complementary if they are to play their part in individual fulfilment.

In a comprehensive statement, the conference noted that education programs must aim to instil in students the principles of democratic life and its foundations; knowledge of the institutions of their country and of a person's rights and responsibilities in today's world; the ability to reflect on the conditions and means of promoting respect for these rights and responsibilities; a capacity for personal reflection and critical analysis; and respect, tolerance and understanding of others. The conference invited members of parliament to urge their respective governments to adopt a global strategy to implement policies to this effect.

Many other meetings were attended by the delegation during the conference. They included meetings of the Asia-Pacific group where prominence was given to the forthcoming IPU Asia-Pacific conference on science and technology to be held in Tokyo, and 12+ Group meetings. The delegation also attended meetings of the executive committee of the Interparliamentary Council. A notable feature of the council's deliberations was its resolution expressing support for the United Nations International Year of the Family. A particular highlight for the delegation was the opening ceremony held in the central hall at parliament house, during which addresses focusing on the ideals of the Interparliamentary Union were made by the President of India and the Prime Minister of India.

Before concluding my remarks, I wish to acknowledge the excellent role undertaken during the conference by the deputy leader of the delegation, Mr David Connolly MP, especially when I became ill, as I shall mention shortly. Thanks are also due to Mr Bill Nelson of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, His Excellency Mr David Evans, the Australian High Commissioner to New Delhi, and Mrs Evans, and members of the staff of the Australian High Commission in New Delhi. The names of many others who rendered particular assistance to the delegation have been noted in the report.

Leaving the good wine almost till last, I express my deep personal gratitude to the untiring and always helpful secretary to the delegation, Ms Anne Hazelton. It was she who summoned medical assistance for me when I was suddenly taken ill and hospitalised. Ms Hazelton unselfishly delayed her return so that she could accompany me when I was once again fit to travel and, during that additional time in New Delhi, she contracted the same complaint that had hospitalised me. It was a complaint which was to persist for both of us for months to come. It is a mark of Ms Hazelton's outstanding dedication that, despite being too ill to come to work for two weeks on her return, she still carried out her duties as IPU conference coordinator and was largely responsible for the highly successful 90th IPU conference hosted by Australia in Canberra in September. I firmly believe that Anne deserves official recognition for her outstanding efforts and achievements for the IPU and for Australia's involvement in that organisation.

Again on a personal basis, I publicly express my extreme thanks to the medical practitioners, the matron and the nursing staff at the hospital in the grounds of the United Kingdom High Commission in New Delhi. I am by no means exaggerating when I mention that it was due to their care that I am able to be here today to report on the 89th conference.

Finally, as I have noted in these remarks, the conference enabled members of parliament from all over the world to meet, discuss and formulate strategies on a number of issues of continuing international significance. On behalf of the delegation, I wish to thank our Indian hosts for their efforts in ensuring a successful conference. I commend the delegation's report to the Senate.

The speech read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: On 27 May 1993 the former Deputy President, Senator Colston, presented the report of the Advisory Committee on the Proposed Creation of a Department of Parliamentary Information and Reporting Services and foreshadowed a response to the committee's recommendations in the Budget Sittings.

The bill now before the Senate implements the recommendations of the committee's majority report which the Speaker and the then President accepted. Accordingly, the bill provides for the creation of the Department of Parliamentary Library and Reporting Services to replace the current Department of the Parliamentary Library (DPL) and the Department of the Parliamentary Reporting Staff (DPRS). The bill provides that the new department will come into existence on 1 July 1994.

The principal advantage of the merger of the two departments will be improvements in the provision of information services to the Parliament. The new department will comprise the Parliamentary Library, Hansard, the Parliamentary Information Systems Office and the Sound and Vision Office, all of which will operate as separate client service programs supported by a single administrative and corporate management structure.

This will give the Parliament two service departments, one providing information services, the other—the Joint House Department—providing physical services. The Speaker and I believe that this structure is the most appropriate and effective one for the Parliament. We do not believe that any further reduction in the number of parliamentary service departments is warranted and we do not intend to propose that there be any further changes.
Background

Recent years have seen major developments in the provision of information services. Increasingly, the services provided by the Parliamentary Library, Hansard, the Parliamentary Information Systems Office and the Sound and Vision Office have become more interrelated and more interdependent. This trend will continue—indeed, accelerate. The merger of DPL and DPRS will place the Parliament in a position to take the maximum advantage of developments in these areas, by bringing about much closer coordination of services and greater financial flexibility.

The bringing together of the two departments into one will allow for greater efficiency in the corporate support areas and will lead to savings of around $1 million over the life of a Parliament. The money saved will be used to enhance services to Senators and Members. The savings will occur only as a result of attrition in staff numbers and only in the corporate services area of the new department. No present staff will lose their jobs, but as individuals are promoted, transferred, retire or resign, the positions vacated will be reviewed, and, where appropriate, not filled. No positions in the client services programs of the new department (that is, in the Library, Hansard, PISO or SAVO) will be affected.

Honourable senators would be aware that the task of supporting the Parliament has grown substantially in recent years, in part as a result of the additional facilities and services available in the new building but also as a result of the expansion of the work of committees of both chambers. The Speaker and I wish to ensure there is maximum cooperation and coordination between the parliamentary departments, consistent with the constitutional independence and roles of the Senate and the House of Representatives.

Meetings of the heads of the parliamentary departments with the Presiding Officers have been a useful means of assisting in this process and the Speaker and I are anxious to continue to develop this positive approach.

However, the Speaker and I believe that there will need to be more frequent and more wide ranging meetings of department heads with the implementation of this proposal. We have therefore decided to establish a more formal coordinating group comprising heads of each parliamentary department to provide an effective forum for ensuring the most efficient use of all resources available to the Parliament.

The advisory committee's first recommendation was that a new parliamentary department be created to replace the Department of the Parliamentary Library and the Department of the Parliamentary Reporting Staff. This recommendation was based on `the opportunity for the generation of savings which could be applied to enhance information services provided to Senators and Members'.

The committee further recommended (Recommendation 4) that the name of the new department be the Department of Parliamentary Library and Reporting Services. This title reflects the historical importance of both library and reporting services to the Parliament.

The committee's second recommendation was that a consultative group comprising representatives of management and staff of both departments be set up for a specified period to assist with the implementation of Recommendation 1. The Speaker and I have accepted this recommendation and have directed that a group be established from the consultative committees of both departments to carry out this task.

The amalgamation of the corporate services areas of the Department of the Parliamentary Reporting Staff and the Department of the Parliamentary Library will result in appreciable financial savings. The committee recommended (Recommendation 3) that the Presiding Officers seek the firm agreement of the Minister for Finance that the total appropriations for the two departments would be maintained in real terms for the new department.

This assurance was given to the advisory committee by the Department of Finance but the committee believed that ministerial level confirmation of this would be appropriate. The Minister for Finance has confirmed this position in a letter dated 21 December 1993.

At present the Parliamentary Librarian is responsible to the Parliament directly through the Presiding Officers and indirectly through the Library Committee. The Secretary to the new department will have administrative responsibility under the Public Service Act for the management and administration of the whole department, but the advisory committee recommended (Recommendation 5) that the Parliamentary Librarian have the right of direct access to the Presiding Officers on library matters and be able to provide advice on matters within his or her professional responsibilities. This arrangement would be similar to that applying to the Chief Hansard Reporter since 1990. The Speaker and I have accepted this recommendation.

The Joint Library Committee provides a forum for Senators and Members to discuss matters relating to the functions of the Parliamentary Library. The advisory committee recommended (Recommendation 6) that the Parliamentary Librarian, as the person with responsibility for the day to day running of the Library, be Secretary to the Library Committee or any equivalent body of Senators and Members. The Speaker and I have accepted this recommendation.
The committee made a number of recommendations designed to preserve the perceived historical importance of the office of Parliamentary Librarian—and, by analogy, that of the head of Hansard.

The first of these was (Recommendation 7) that the positions of Parliamentary Librarian and Chief Hansard Reporter be statutory offices created under the Public Service Act 1922. The bill implements that recommendation, the purpose of which is to prevent the positions being abolished by administrative action and to ensure that they can be dispensed with only by the Parliament's amending the Public Service Act. The proposed provision would not give the occupant of either position the authority or responsibility of a departmental secretary.

Three offices are directly affected by the terms of the committee's recommendations: the Secretary to the new department, the Parliamentary Librarian and the Chief Hansard Reporter. The committee recommended (Recommendation 8) that, in order to ensure that the positions were filled on merit, and were seen to be filled on merit, the positions of head of the new department, Parliamentary Librarian and Chief Hansard Reporter be advertised. The Speaker and I have accepted that recommendation as well as the consequent recommendation (Recommendation 9) that the Library Committee be consulted on the composition of selection panels for the positions of head of the new department and Parliamentary Librarian. The Speaker and I would anticipate a member of the Library Committee being on the selection panels for the latter positions.

As a program of the new department, the Parliamentary Library will report on its operations as part of the new department's annual report. However, the committee has recommended (Recommendation 10) that a report from the Parliamentary Librarian in respect of his or her responsibilities be included in the annual report of the department. This recommendation will be implemented by including a specific Parliamentary Librarian's report in the new department's annual report.

The committee's final recommendation, Recommendation 11, refers to the tabling of the committee's report in both Houses of Parliament. This recommendation has already been implemented by the tabling of the report on 27 May.

The committee suggested, though not as a formal recommendation, that the Presiding Officers make a statement of principle concerning the Library's independence. The committee identified two areas where, potentially, the Library's ability to serve the Parliament could be affected: firstly, reduction of services through management intervention, and, secondly, emphasis on technological feasibility rather than client information requirements.

The continuation of the Library Committee, with unchanged terms of reference, and the ability of the Parliamentary Librarian to go directly to the Presiding Officers on library professional matters will provide significant safeguards against such eventualities.

Nevertheless, the Speaker and I place on record our commitment to the importance of the Parliamentary Library's role as a provider of independent information, research and advice to Senators and Members of all parties, as well as independent Senators and Members. The Speaker and I are also committed to the Library continuing to be funded at a level to enable it properly to meet client needs.

The committee commented on the need to clarify the roles and functions of the Parliamentary Information Systems Office (PISO) and its clients, principally the other parliamentary departments. This has been addressed by the Senior Management Coordination Group (SMCG) of the five parliamentary departments in its report Review of the relationship between the parliamentary departments and PISO: roles, responsibilities and funding arrangements, which has been endorsed by the heads of the parliamentary departments and by the Speaker and me.

Paragraphs 5.10.9 to 5.10.11 of the advisory committee's report suggest the need for a review to clarify the functions and roles of the various information providers within the Parliament. Some aspects of this have been addressed in the SMCG report referred to, but the possibility of overlap between the information services offered by the Library and those offered by some other parliamentary departments is a matter of which the Speaker and I would hope all departments would be mindful.

Although members of both the Government and the Opposition from both the Senate and the House of Representatives endorsed the majority report, three committee members produced a minority, dissenting report recommending that the proposed creation of the new department not proceed. As indicated by the introduction of the bill now before the Senate, this recommendation is not accepted by the Speaker and me.

The minority report also recommended that the majority and minority reports be tabled and debated before the Speaker and I make any response to the report and the dissenting report. The first part of this recommendation has been complied with.

The Speaker and I have considered the second part of the recommendation and have come to the conclusion that debate on the legislation currently before the Senate will provide Senators and Members with considerable opportunity to make their views known, particularly since they have had the opportunity to put their views to the committee.

To ensure that Senators and Members had time properly to consider the proposal, which was first circulated to Senators and Members in September 1992, debate on this bill has not been brought on until now, more than two months after it was introduced into the House of Representatives and 18 months after the proposition was first put forward.

The creation of the new department will benefit the Parliament by providing the potential for better information services to Senators and Members, better integration of available and future technologies and the ability to use a greater proportion of the Parliament's resources on direct service delivery to Senators and Members as a result of more cost-effective corporate support structures.
As a separate program of the new department, the Library will maintain its identity and high profile, just as Hansard has since the reorganisation of DPRS in 1990.
The objective of the new department will be to provide the Parliament with library, reporting, information technology and communications services of the highest possible quality.

I reiterate the thanks of the Speaker and me to all members of the advisory committee for their very careful and thoughtful consideration of the proposal. I also thank all those individuals and organisations which assisted the committee in its deliberations.
I commend the bill to the Senate and present the explanatory memorandum.
