TALK.START.PARA: —Before the debate was interrupted, Senator Teague concluded his remarks on the second reading of the Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill 1993. This bill amends the Higher Education Funding Act 1988. Among other financial adjustments, it provides for funding of 1,500 increased places for undergraduate students. That number includes 500 additional places to be jointly funded with industry. We look forward to industry playing an increased role in some areas of education provision in the higher education sector. We will monitor the success of the pilot program, which promotes closer cooperation between industry and universities. Whilst it is important that these courses are relevant to industry's needs, we do not want to see education beholden to industry and any other business or employment sectors. Of course, education has intrinsic value in its own right.

PARA.TAB: The Democrats welcome those additional places. We have strongly supported growth in the higher education sector for the past five years. We are committed to sustainable growth in higher education institutions, and condemn the fact that increased places have not been matched with funding for staffing infrastructure and capital works, as would be appropriate. We acknowledge there has been increased funding, but not to the extent that should have occurred to match those extra places. Groups such as the Australian Vice-Chancellors Committee and the national student and academic groups of CAPA, NTEU and NUS support funding for at least an additional 4,500 places over the next three years to meet the level of demand for higher education places.

The concerns of the opposition regarding the allocation of increased places does not have a political basis. It has a political bias, but not a political basis. We support the creation of places on a needs basis. We do not believe the political circumstances are properly addressed by the coalition's concerns.

This bill has, in its own way, stirred up the fees debate yet again. That was evidenced by Senator Teague's speech earlier today. I note that the first press release of the new Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Crean) on the subject sought to clarify the fact that this bill does not raise the level of HECS payments, and I also note that that is not for want of trying. We saw evidence of that in the budget. Despite a purported commitment to access and equity in higher education by this government, the budget last year contained two punitive and regressive measures. Firstly, there was a minimum time rule which would penalise students who failed to complete their course in a certain time. Students so involved would incur a 50 per cent HECS increase for each additional unit studied. Secondly, there was the proposal for a doubling of the HECS rate for second degrees, which would hit hardest at women, part-time, mature-aged and Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander students, and which would see Australian students saddled with debts of around $45,000 for those who choose to undertake a second undergraduate degree and take out a student loan to facilitate that process. These measures were defeated by the combined forces of the Australian Democrats and the opposition in the Senate.

The Democrats' commitment to a fair and accessible education system is well known, but the opposition's decision to join with us in the interests of Australian students was a pleasing, if not expected, turn of events. It is with interest that I have viewed statements by the shadow minister, Dr Wooldridge, when debating this bill in the other place, and Senator Teague, when contributing to this debate today, in calling for the government to allow institutions to charge fees for undergraduate places. This call and those speeches seem strangely at odds with the coalition's newfound enlightenment when it comes to some parts of education funding. Logic would indicate that if opposition members are genuinely opposed to user pays education, as expressed in their previous votes here, they would not advocate up-front full-cost fees for Australian students, nor allow entry—as Senator Teague said—`for whoever on whatever grounds'. They would not be saying such things which would make our education system one for an elite, rich group. The Democrats do oppose, and will continue to oppose, the entrenchment of user pays principles in education. We do not support fees for education at any level—primary, secondary or tertiary.

Only this week we have seen a flurry of press interest in the high levels of fees and charges in our state school systems. We often see this at the beginning of the school year, when people realise there is no such thing as compulsory free education in Australia. The fees, levies, or whatever one might like to call them, which are being charged in our state schools are rising, to the extent that they are parallel with some of the fees being charged in so-called independent schools. This is a situation which has been of particular concern to the Democrats lately, and we will continue to pursue this matter.

I come back to this particular bill, which deals with a suite of problems associated with higher education. I put opposition members on notice—not that they need to be—that their proposal for fees for above quota places will not be supported by us, which would not surprise them. Education in this country is coming with a rising price tag. Let us be clear that it is government and opposition policy; they are in concert in this regard. The government and the opposition are creating a situation where parents and students are being required to pay more for what is essentially government's responsibility to provide, in an equal and equitable fashion, education for all Australians.

The Democrats welcome the targeting of places in regional areas and areas of population growth, but we do share some of the coalition's expressed concerns about the way those places are being allocated.

TALK.START.PARA: —How did Tassie do?

—To answer the interjection by Senator Tierney, I am particularly disappointed that Tasmania has not been advantaged by this strange policy of the government. The claims by the coalition that places are being created on political grounds may be far-fetched and may highlight the fact its only concern about this bill is for political point scoring purposes.

PARA.TAB: The Democrats support the concerns of student and education groups regarding the discriminatory nature of quotas on undergraduate places for mature aged students. Growth in higher education enrolments and participation rates have, more or less, been in favour of postgraduate students. We have witnessed unprecedented levels of unmet demands in the 1990s amongst our school leavers.

While it is undeniable that more places are required for undergraduate entrants, those places should not be at the expense of mature aged students. I concur with Senator Teague's observations about the qualities of mature aged students; that, by and large, such students are highly motivated and quite successful in their pursuit of tertiary studies. For the community at large, for the whole of the Australian nation, such students represent a very good investment. The amount of time, effort and money invested in meeting the needs of such students is well rewarded because of the normally high degree of motivation displayed by such students. We agree with Senator Teague that all students should have their place in the sun and the opportunity to pursue educational training. But that will not occur if the coalition has its way with fees and charges.

While additional places have been created for postgraduate students, we take issue with the massive deregulation of the postgraduate sector. Course fees for postgraduate students in this sector range from $5,000 to $35,000. There is no quality control. There are no adequate grievance procedures. This system is so unregulated that it really is starting to become a bit of a rort. If people such as Senator Tierney—who is about to contribute to this debate—are genuinely interested in this area, a little attention should be paid to this sector. Rather, it is being followed up in a fairly cavalier way.

It seems as though a bit of political ideology is being followed here: if money is being charged for it and money is being paid for it, it is all right. It seems to reflect free enterprise. It is more laissez faire than anything else, is it not? It seems as though almost anything can go in this area. We really should be a little more cautious about endorsing such proposals. We are certainly very cautious about looking upon this growth with approval because it is threatening to overtake the traditional role of universities.

The Auditor-General's audit report No. 14 of 1993-94, which deals with growth, change and equity in higher education, shows that grants per EFTSU have increased only moderately during the period 1989-91. That is one of the highest growth periods for secondary school retention and university entrance application—the two follow each other, of course. The reality is that, per student unit, funding is lower today than it was in 1983 when this government came into office. That is hardly something of which to be proud. It is a sad indictment of this government's alleged commitment to a fair education system. Those figures expose the rhetoric about making this a clever country.

I wish to refer to an associated matter that is also contained in this bill. Many of today's students are identified by a tax file number. The Democrats find that a regrettable feature of today's education system. The excuse for that—which the Democrats understand—is that, in order for students to repay their HECS debt through the taxation system, they have to be taxpayers and therefore have to have a tax file number. That is understandable if students want to use the deferred payment option and not pay the HECS fee up-front. It is obviously necessary that such students must supply the Australian Taxation Office and the education institution with a tax file number.

This bill supposedly improves the arrangements for quoting tax file numbers in those circumstances. But the procedures outlined in the proposed amendments are, we believe, unnecessarily harsh. Proposed new sections 41B and 41C will allow an institution to cancel the enrolment of students who have not provided their tax file number. The bill explains the time limit for provision of that number. I foreshadow here our intention to amend section 42A to allow a period of grace of 56 days—two months—as opposed to 28 days.

This whole area smacks of another example of how the tax file number has almost become an accessory for living in Australia. It is a requirement for so many diverse areas of human endeavour that it has become an identifier—something that citizens have to cart about with them and be identified by—before they are allowed to participate in any of an increasing number of activities which normal citizens should be able to pursue without such a provision.

I must say that I find myself in a unique position here today in agreeing with Senator David MacGibbon. He expressed his concern earlier today about the need for veterans and people in receipt of disability pensions or some other pensions from the Department of Veterans' Affairs—payments which do not rely in any way upon people's taxpaying status, even if such people may not be taxpayers—to supply a tax file number to receive such payments. As I said, this is a unique experience for me to actually be in agreement with Senator MacGibbon but I do agree with his concern.

In the education system we have an increasing requirement to provide a tax file number. As I said, I foreshadow seeking to amend that provision to at least allow people a greater amount of time to provide that. We have been told that there are administrative reasons, and perhaps even institutional reasons, for the period not being too long. But I only have to instance the experience of my own daughter—who, at 16 years of age, recently applied for a tax file number—to dispute that. After acquiring her birth certificate and identifiers such as bank accounts, tickets and all the other bits of chits of paper required to fill out the form properly, she was told that it would take only a couple of days to get her number. In fact, it was almost three weeks after the date of her application that she received the number. If she had been in the situation of registering at a university, it would have been a pretty close call between her enrolment and having to withdraw. Even in that instance, the administration and bureaucracy could have fallen over itself a little earlier.

The Democrats do have a proud record of standing up for the rights and privacy of Australians. It is something that the coalition seems to have abandoned recently, despite its claim to liberal principles. It is something which the government has certainly long since abandoned. Increasingly, the freedom of speech or free press and privacy are threatened. The intrusive use of tax file numbers is only one example of this. Our campaign against the Australia card will be remembered as an example of our defence of the liberties and personal rights of all Australians. I intend to continue that.

Clause 9 of this bill provides for funding adjustments to the open learning initiative. The Democrats believe that open learning should be an exciting technological advance that brings education a step closer for all Australians, especially those who are traditionally disadvantaged by distance, by home duties or by disabilities of one sort or another. But these groups will not be able to access the OLI if they have to pay prohibitive up-front course fees. I was glad to see the government introduce the deferred payment scheme for open learning in last year's budget after pressure from the Democrats and student groups.

We will continue the push for the minimum course load requirement to qualify for the deferred scheme to be reduced from 75 per cent of the course load to at least 50 per cent, especially for those students who may be unable, for physical or employment reasons, to take the minimum 75 per cent load. That would concur with established practice for open learning and/or distance educational institutions internationally and in Australia in previous years.

The bill also appropriately exempts some students from HECS, including certain New Zealand citizens. It clarifies the classification of work experience and it supports offers of redundancy payments to excess staff. Many of these measures could be described as merely administrative functions which tighten up previous loopholes or inconsistencies. Of course, the Democrats will be supporting those changes. In short, this bill is an attempt to tidy up parts of the government education system, but real commitment to access and equity in education is not revealed by this package.

TALK.START.PARA: I rise to speak on the Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill. I begin by following on from the final point raised by Senator Bell. He described this bill as a tidying up exercise for higher education, but I think it is a little more than that. I think that in tidying up the government is revealing a number of glaring errors in the system to date. I want to deal with two of those.

PARA.TAB: The first major aspect of the bill is in regard to the increase in the maximum level of recurrent grants, and related to that is the increase in grants for the superannuation guarantee levy. The bill also adjusts funds for open learning institutions over the 1993-95 triennium. This is due to the lower than expected demand for places in 1993. Finally, the bill clarifies the operation of the tax file number for students who take out loans from the Commonwealth.

As indicated by Senator Teague earlier, the coalition is not opposing the provisions of this bill but I think we need to focus on a number of measures and to really take a hard look at the failings of some aspects of the government's higher education policy as revealed by these measures. One of the most startling measures I found was the fact that the bill is announcing, two to three years ahead, the funding of precisely 1,500 new additional intake places.

I realise we are on a system of triennial funding, but I am intrigued at the way in which this figure is so neatly tied down, and at the rather curious way in which it is proposed that universities will gain these places on the criteria being set by the government. One would have thought that in an expanding economy, which the government is touting greatly at this point, one of the benefits would perhaps be more funding so that higher education could fund more places. Who knows at this point how many might be funded? But we are tied down to this rather peculiar figure of 1,500.

The government has set out the basis on which it will allocate these numbers and, on the surface, it looks like quite a reasonable proposition. The government says that regions of high population growth and low tertiary education participation will receive priority. I do not think anyone could really argue with those overall criteria. They are two areas to which the government should direct funding. But then it brings in a rather strange secondary list of criteria, the basis on which one can receive this funding if one jumps over these particular government hurdles. As I read through the list I was increasingly amazed at how centralised our system has become if universities have to jump through all these hoops. One would have thought that with the dismantling of the communist system in eastern Europe we had seen the last of this sort of heavy-handed centralised control—

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh dear, Senator!

—Let me take Senator Crowley through some of the provisions here, or some of the hoops that one has to jump through to get these places. I would like to put it in the context of the prize that is at the end of the tunnel. We are looking at 1,500 places across 36 universities. We have, as I will indicate a little later, excluded a number of states. Senator Bell indicated earlier that his state was one of the ones missed. But we are looking at only 1,500 places across a total of 36 universities. If we quickly do our maths, I think it comes down to something like 45 places per university.

PARA.TAB: This is not a great prize, but the following hurdles have to be jumped over. Firstly, the universities have to show they have links with industry. Secondly, they have to show they are innovative in their modes of delivery of education, whatever that means. Excellence in modes of delivery of education is a very commendable thing, but I would like to know on an objective basis how one gets out there and measures it and how one determines the modes of delivery at the University of Western Australia are superior to the University of New South Wales—across what range of faculties and what staff—without employing a great army of bureaucrats to run around and measure such things.

There is also the extent to which agreed school leaver targets and undergraduate targets have been met. This is being set up by the government in a very centralised way even though in estimates DEET keeps telling us how decentralised it is becoming and how much decision making is moved back to the level of the universities. Time and again we come across things like this which show that that objective is a nonsense. As I move around the universities of Australia vice-chancellors and other senior officers tell me it is a nonsense. It is backed up by that point as well.

There are equity group success rates and graduate employment outcomes, and also the quality of higher education provision. I assume that means resources, teachers and the way in which the programs are put together. Again, how do we measure that? The current push for allocating funding on a quality base will run into enormous problems because it involves trying to measure things that cannot be measured in a reliable, valid way.

TALK.START.PARA: —Therefore, don't measure at all.

—Are you suggesting, Senator, that we measure them with incorrect measuring instruments and allocate on an incorrect basis? I am glad that the honourable senator's profession of medicine never operated on that sort of slapdash basis and that doctors are fairly precise in the measurements they provide, the doses they provide, and that they provide them to the right patients. In this case they will not be provided to the right patients because the sorts of measures being used are very difficult to use. My basic point is that the government has come up with this rather strange set of criteria to allocate very few places across the university system and, out of government money, is allocating a miserable 1,000 places across the whole university sector.

PARA.TAB: Also, we have this joint funding of industry. I have nothing against that particular idea, but I think we are a bit short on detail. Firstly, how was that figure of 500 actually arrived at? How do we actually work out where those places will be? Do we know which industries and which faculties this money will be allocated to? I doubt whether we know that at this stage. The whole way in which this exercise was undertaken is yet another example of intrusion into university autonomy. It has centralised control written all over it.

Let us have a look at how these 1,500 places are broken down by regions. We actually see a very curious pattern. My state, New South Wales, does reasonably well. It has 350, so it has about one-third. New South Wales has about one-third of Australia's population, so I suppose that is fine. But where are the 350 going? They are going to Dubbo, Coffs Harbour, Lismore, Ourimbah and Shoalhaven. Admittedly these are within the parameters of growth areas, and I understand that, but the net effect, given that the cities of New South Wales are predominantly the areas where the largest population is found and where there is the easiest access to universities, is that there is absolutely no growth in the major university centres in Sydney, Wollongong or Newcastle.

The only growth that exists in the system is on the periphery. We need growth there, but it should not lead to there being no growth anywhere else. This highlights the point that the government is not putting enough money into this sector. There should be growth, as the vice-chancellor's claim, of 6000, not 1,500. If the government really stood by what it should be doing, it would be funding places in 1996 at four times the rate that it is doing now. With a rising boom, one would think it would be able to afford to do that, but it is not. It is starving an already starved university sector of funding. The infrastructure is running down, the standards of conditions of academic staff are running down, and the quality of education is running down, yet these people are getting no growth at all.

Having just discussed New South Wales, I note that, regionally, the states of Victoria, South Australia, Tasmania and the Northern Territory received absolutely no growth at all. If I can pick on Victoria, it is hard to understand why outer Melbourne is not considered a population growth area. That is supposed to be one of the criteria, yet that area is getting no places at all. One would have thought that educational disadvantage existed in regional Victoria, but it is not getting any funding at all under this rather peculiar system.

With all due deference to my colleague Senator Reid, I see that the Australian Capital Territory is doing very well under this system. It has a very high tertiary participation rate and obviously it must be getting in on this act on the basis of being the second fastest growing part of the country. Again, there is plenty of provision in this area but in regional Australia and the more isolated and distant states there certainly is not.

The second aspect of this bill that I want to discuss briefly is: what happens under this amendment bill to funding for open learning? I have discussed this in the parliament a number of times. I raise again the issue of and the great concern about the developments in open learning in this country over the last two years. I make it perfectly clear that I am a great supporter of the concept of open learning. I was a student under it, and a lecturer and a director in this field. But I have been increasingly disturbed over recent years about the way in which open learning is going. We had a system that seemed to be working quite well. We had across the country nine distance education centres. We had concentrated open learning to some extent in a number of universities. They were developing their resources and programs in a way which was providing increasing excellence in education for people in isolated areas.

Before the 1993 election we had—I believe this was largely an election ploy—the promise to provide a lot more places for higher education through open learning. That sounded good on the surface, but the reality was that the government was using it as a political ploy.Highly embarrassed by having more than 50,000 students not gaining places at universities, the government had this magic panacea that people could learn by television. It created what it called the open learning initiative and, in typical Labor government fashion, centralised it immediately in one spot.

There were many concerns about the process and the way in which this actually happened. We ended up with Monash University running this open learning system and contracting out work to the other institutions. This scheme has huge question marks over it in terms of funding and the quality outcomes which will come from such a low funding level. This has been raised before in the parliament and in estimates committees. One of the things which show the failure of the scheme is its take-up rate.

I was criticised last year in the newspapers for commenting on the fact that the scheme was failing and that there was not a take-up rate. Lo and behold, the facts are out now; the figures are there. The government is finding that the money it allocated in 1993 could not fully be taken up. It has had to reallocate it across 1994 and 1995. We find that $15.8 million of this funding could not be spent because we had a situation where the enrolments were 3,000 and not the expected 8,000 to 14,000. So the government's claim before the election that it had a solution for the problems in higher education is revealed as a complete sham when only 3,000 students are enrolled in the system right across Australia.

Despite the fact that this open learning agency is struggling to meet its budget, despite the fact that the whole system is over-engineered and over-controlled, the government is persisting with an inappropriate system—one which has enormous funding difficulties, given that only $300 per unit is allowed to educate students. Having taught in this area, I do not quite know what $300 would buy. It certainly does not buy a good tuition system, it certainly does not buy a good communications system and it certainly does not buy an effective assessment system. Basically, what one gets for $300 is a video tape, a few notes, and not much help at all. I would not think that is the provision of quality learning.

One of the most insidious things about the system is the way in which it is bleeding resources from other universities. They join in with the system but receive funding only at a marginal rate. They do not even get the full $300. That is discounted by Monash, and they actually end up with $195 per unit. One cannot fund much for that.

There are huge questions over this area of open learning and the way in which the government has run it through the open learning initiative; questions which I will be taking up further in the estimates committee. In this bill this shortcoming is shown up by the fact that funding for 1993 was not spent. Serious questions must be asked about the provision of further funding in the next few years and whether that will be taken up as well.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to respond to a number of points in respect of the contributions made by Senator Teague, Senator Bell and Senator Tierney. Firstly, Senator Teague made some comments on the growth in higher education and the allocation of places. The 1996 growth of 1,000 additional places was allocated to areas of greatest need, as indicated by regions with high population growth and low tertiary education participation. The additional places were therefore allocated as follows: Queensland, 400; Western Australia, 200; New South Wales, 370; and the Australian Capital Territory, 30.

PARA.TAB: I would like to refer to the position in Victoria, South Australia, Tasmania and the Northern Territory. Firstly, places are not being allocated away from Victoria, as is suggested in the Victorian minister's press release that was incorporated in Hansard this morning. Victoria has previously received well above its population share of Commonwealth funded places. Victoria's share of places is above the population share and the rate of participation is well above the national average. Of some 393,000 persons with degree qualifications in Victoria in February 1993, only 278,000 were employed. That represents a smaller proportion than for the rest of Australia. In addition, Victoria's participation rate in higher education was 55 persons per thousand in 1992 compared with a national average of 50.

Secondly, it would be irrational for the Commonwealth to allocate places to a state which, in real terms, is already above its share. If the Commonwealth were to attempt to equalise shares of places—which, of course, it is not—Victoria would lose some 12,000 places. In addition to the 1,000 additional places funded for 1996, 500 new joint Commonwealth-industry places will be available on a competitive basis. In previous years Victoria has received over 50 per cent of these. Given Victoria's industrial base, it could be expected to attract a sizeable number of such places again.

South Australia and Tasmania have a projected population growth rate of well below the national average. In respect to the Northern Territory, while eligible in the sense of meeting the allocation criteria, the size of the available pool of 1,000 means that the allocation for the Northern Territory would have been too small to be meaningful.

With respect to mature age students, the effect of the introduction of school leavers targets will be to restore the school leaver share of commencing undergraduate places to 1990 levels—around 50 per cent. Mature age applicants and non-school leavers should not be disadvantaged as they will also make up 50 per cent of commencing students.

The school leaver targets do not use an age criterion and, therefore, do not exclude mature age students entering higher education directly from secondary education. Not all mature age students are offered a higher education place on the basis of a tertiary entrance score. There is not enough information at this stage to determine whether the introduction of school leaver targets has had an effect on opportunities for mature age students. The government has provided funding for some 11,000 new higher education places in 1994, a significant number of which will be taken by mature age students.

Senator Teague said he was disappointed that the open learning initiative did not appear to be reaching the projected number of students. The government has provided funding of more than $52 million over the 1993-95 triennium for the open learning initiative to support the establishment and operation of an independent open learning organisation, the Open Learning Agency of Australia, OLAA, and the establishment of an open learning electronic support service to provide enhanced student support services. Contrary to the remarks by Senator Teague, the department expects around 20,000 enrolments in 1994, in line with expectations.

In respect of Senator Bell's comments, the clauses he has proposed for amendment need to be read in conjunction with clause 42(3) and (5) of the bill. The 28-day period is only to apply after a student has obtained or sought a tax file number from the Australian Taxation Office and the ATO has advised the institution that there is a problem with the tax file number quoted by the student. This would only happen after the Australian Taxation Office had not been able to correct the problem after consultation with the student—for example, where a student quotes a false tax file number. An increase in the period allowed for the student to correct the situation is therefore unlikely to assist the student in these cases. An extension to 56 days would prevent the institution from reallocating a place in that semester.

In respect of the comments made by Senator Tierney, the challenge facing the government is to address community expectations for access to higher education in areas of high population growth and low tertiary education participation. A working party will be set up to consider the criteria and to circulate a discussion paper for consultation with the higher education sector, the vice-chancellors, the students and the academics.
Amendment agreed to.
Original question, as amended, resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
The bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1)Clause 15, page 6, line 31, proposed paragraph 42A(1)(b), omit "28 days", substitute "56 days".
(2)Clause 19, page 7, line 30, proposed paragraph 106 AA(1)(b), omit "28 days", substitute "56 days".

I gave the reasons for these amendments during the second reading debate. Although there is some degree of truth in what he said, an additional set of problems has been introduced because the tax file number will be used for more than taxation purposes. Intruding into a student's ability to enrol by introducing extra impediments in requiring a tax file number in certain circumstances deprives those students who are qualified to enter a tertiary institution. Such an impediment is neither just nor equitable. The government is purportedly concerned about access and equity in education but this impediment is not the right way to go.

PARA.TAB: I will persist with the amendments in the hope of bringing to the attention of the government the inequities caused by introducing these tax file numbers into the education system. After all, tax file numbers have nothing to do with education; they are supposed to be part of the administration of the Australian taxation system and, as such, have no place in education. If tax file numbers are to be used, students should have sufficient time in which to get their affairs in order and should in no way face any impediment. I will persist with the amendments even though the parliamentary secretary has given reasons for the government not supporting them.

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition does not support the amendments moved by Senator Bell. In no way does the opposition condone or give any kind of support for any inappropriate use of a tax file number, but that will not happen under this legislation. Rather, students involved in a contract for the higher education contribution scheme—those who have a tax liability—will be identified by their tax file number. That is, with regard to a tax matter there is a tax file number. PARA.TAB: However, serious consequences would flow by extending the 28-day period. Some of these problems might arise even within the 28 days. There needs to be certainty and responsibility for information on the part of the student in the administration of something like the higher education contribution scheme. TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Offshore Minerals Bill is to be debated cognately with the Offshore Minerals (Consequential Provisions) Bill, the Offshore Minerals (Retention Licence Fees) Bill and the Minerals (Submerged Lands)(Royalty) Amendment Bill, all of which are subsequent to and dependent upon the main Bill. The purpose of the Offshore Minerals Bill 1993 and subsequent bills is to replace the existing Minerals (Submerged Lands) Act 1981 and to amend its associated acts.

PARA.TAB: The main function of this package of bills is to establish a uniform mining code for all offshore Commonwealth and state jurisdictions in regard to the exploration and production of all non-petroleum minerals. Offshore petroleum mining is regulated by the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Act 1967. I will not go into a debate on this bill as the National-Liberal coalition is supporting it without amendment. The package of bills is designed to facilitate a consistent administration of offshore non-petroleum exploration and production and to bring it in line with modern mining administration practices. There are currently only a couple of active offshore mineral explorations—one on the Ord River in the Kimberley region, and the other in South Australia's Spencer Gulf. It is anticipated that mineral exploration will increasingly move offshore in the future and will become a significant addition to the huge export earnings of the total mining industry. This bill, therefore, will become more relevant over the next few years.

According to a recent ABARE outlook conference, mining industry total earnings for 1994-95 are forecast to rise to $33.4 billion. The mining industry currently provides around 160,000 direct jobs and 470,000 indirect jobs. It is a major contributor to our national wealth. Legislation that proposes to streamline the administration of any facet of the industry—in this case the exploration and production of offshore mining—deserves, and will get, our utmost support.

It is important to note that the Offshore Minerals Bill 1993 retains the key principles of the original act, which have a direct effect on the states. The principles include the provision that all offshore mineral activity in the Commonwealth area, adjacent to state waters, is governed by a joint authority consisting of the relevant state and Commonwealth ministers. The joint authorities are responsible for the major decisions relating to grants of title. The administration of Commonwealth legislation is carried out by the relevant state government in relation to the granting of permits, licences and fees for exploration, which is fitting as land management is an important function of the states. The existing 60 to 40 royalty split in favour of the states is also retained.

Before the drafting of this bill, widespread consultation with the state governments and the specific industries involved—such as the Association of Mining and Exploration Companies, AMEC, and the Australian and New Zealand Minerals and Energy Council—have taken place over the past few years. It is anticipated that subsequent to the passage of this bill, the states and territories will introduce their own offshore minerals legislation to complement that of the Commonwealth. It will enable a uniform minerals code to apply all around Australia. The fact that this positive outcome is anticipated is due to the harmonious nature of the consultative process between the state governments and the Commonwealth, which I have touched on already.

I would like to state how pleased I am to be speaking on this bill. It has eventuated as a result of the states and the Commonwealth working in harmony. It is unlike the bitter debates we have engaged in over such things as the Native Title Bill, and over the relationship between state governments and the Commonwealth in regard to land management. This bill represents the positive outcome that can result from a cooperative effort between both levels of government. As the shadow minister for resources and energy, Peter McGauran, stated in his speech on the second reading, this bill is a model of the cooperation that the Native Title Bill should have attracted.

I will now discuss briefly the main provisions of the related bills in this package. The Offshore Minerals (Consequential Provisions) 1993 repeals the Minerals (Submerged Lands) Act 1981. It also amends the Associated Fees Act. The Offshore Minerals (Retention Licence Fees) Bill 1993 deals with fees payable for the retention of licences. It introduces a new form of retention licence and provides for an annual fee to cover administrative costs.

The retention licence enables a permit holder to retain a proved mineral deposit without working it, if there is good reason for deferring the production stage. The fee structure for the new retention licence is consistent with other fee structures covering exploration permits and production licences in the existing acts.

The Minerals (Submerged Lands)(Royalty) Amendment Bill 1993 amends the Royalty Act. However, these amendments are purely technical in nature and do not affect the royalty liabilities of mining companies or the distribution of their royalties. We all know that exploration for mineral deposits in offshore areas always gives rise to environmental concerns.

I understand that the Australian Democrats will be moving amendments in relation to this. The coalition will not support these amendments as we believe their concerns in this regard are not warranted. I have been advised that mining exploration and production is already excluded from marine parks, as set down in the parks management report. There is no need for an amendment to prohibit mining in marine parks when it is already forbidden.

The Offshore Minerals Bill 1993 requires that any application for offshore mineral titles must meet the requirements of the Environmental (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974. It should be stated that mining companies in recent years have become very aware of their responsibilities to the environment. They have become far more environmentally conscious. They should be applauded for their continued efforts in this very important area.

With regard to the Democrats' other amendments concerning confidentiality of information given by mining companies to the designated authority, it is my understanding that there is already a provision in clause 376 or part 4 of the main bill relating to information management that deals adequately with this.

In my role as shadow minister for northern Australia and external territories, I would like to acknowledge the external territory offshore area covered in clause 14 in the main bill. This clause provides that our island territories of Ashmore, Cartier Islands, Norfolk Island, Heard Island, McDonald Island and Christmas and Cocos (Keeling) Islands are included in the adjacent areas provision. Christmas and Cocos (Keeling) Islands are not included in adjacent areas in the external territory offshore section in the current act, so the provisions in this bill to include them are welcomed.

I would like to conclude my statement by praising the use of the new plain English style in the drafting of these bills. The use of plain English language makes the bill far easier to read and certainly promotes a clearer understanding of its scope and purpose. The coalition supports the Offshore Minerals Bill 1993 and allied bills before the Senate and their successful passage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Boswell has just pointed out, the Offshore Minerals Bill 1993 and allied bills are the end result of a long negotiation between the federal government and several state governments. It is unlikely that the alternative views, which I will now put, will be acceptable to the government. It may well be that the amendments that I will be putting later on will be unacceptable to the government.We are well aware that in the past when there have been such things as agreements between the states or international agreements we have had great difficulty in changing the federal government's view in relation to quite specific amendments. It is partly for that reason that the Australian Democrats will be agreeing to the package of bills currently before the Senate.

PARA.TAB: Nonetheless, I would like to say a few things about these bills and about the philosophy that lies behind them. The package of bills currently before the Senate consists of four individual bills, namely, the Offshore Minerals Bill 1993, the Offshore Minerals (Consequential Provisions) Bill 1993, the Offshore Minerals (Retention Licence Fees) Bill 1993 and the Minerals (Submerged Lands) (Royalty) Amendment Bill 1993. As I have indicated, I will be moving amendments at the committee stage.

The Offshore Minerals Bill 1993, which is the principal bill, replaces the Minerals (Submerged Lands) Act of 1983 which is repealed by the Offshore Minerals (Consequential Provisions) Bill. It establishes a licensing system for the conduct of offshore minerals resource development that may be undertaken in an area under Commonwealth jurisdiction. The bill is limited to mineral resources other than petroleum. It defines minerals as including sand, gravel, clay, limestone, rock, evaporite—I warn the minister that I will have a question on exactly what evaporite is when we get to the committee stage—shale, oil shale and coal.

The Offshore Minerals Bill contains four licensing systems: exploration, retention, mining and works licences. The retention licence is a new form of licence introduced by this bill. According to a briefing prepared by the Minister for Resources (Mr Beddall), it is intended to be an intermediate form of minerals tenure between the exploration permit and the production licence.

The retention licence will allow a permit holder to retain title over an area for up to five years at a time without engaging in commercial activity. Although this sounds suspiciously like resource security for the mining industry, I am pleased that the renewal of the licence is not automatic. I will return to that point again in a minute. Licence holders will have to justify why they should continue to hold a retention licence. If the designated authority is not convinced of the merits of the case, the title will resume to the Commonwealth. The bill describes the kinds of conditions that can be attached to each of the four licences provided in the bill.

When one turns to clause 10(1) of the bill one finds an interesting definition of how the position of a licence will be described. Among other things, it describes the earth as a spheroid and states that the position is to be worked out by reference to a spheroid that has a major equatorial radius of six million and so many metres and a flattening of so much.

This draws our attention to the fact that what we are talking about here is the mining of a finite resource. I think this is a very important point at which to begin some of my remarks. The conventional economic wisdom, the wisdom that drives this government and this opposition, the wisdom that lies behind this legislation, is based on a widely held view which we believe to be false—namely, that resources are infinitely available and that we can go on exploiting them without detriment to the needs, aspirations and options available to future generations. In this bill we have the definition that the earth is a spheroid of a limited size. Clearly, then, the resources which are available to this and all future generations are limited.

The economic rationalist view, the market driven view, the deregulatory view and the small government view which predominates throughout government and opposition at this time says that resources are infinitely available because of two things. As we become richer both in technology and dollars we will be in a better position to recycle these resources to make the resources infinitely substitutable, and to use different technology to exploit resources.

It just so happens that when we look at the figures we find that since the Second World War the economy, according to the conventional measure of growth, has grown by a factor of three. Taking out the inflation factor, GDP per capita is now three times larger than it was at the end of the Second World War. Despite that, we are told repeatedly that we cannot afford to attack many of our major environmental problems such as greenhouse. Despite the supposed unlimited increase in human ingenuity and technical progress, we are still apparently unable to tackle some of these fundamental environmental problems which are advancing at a pace, despite the increase in wealth as measured by per capita GDP.

What the economists, the opposition and the government are failing to recognise is that there is an inexorability about the run-down of resources. The second law of thermodynamics, perhaps the most fundamental law of the universe, tells us that as we go to lower grades of resources, as we exploit the earth's riches, the amounts of energy and complexity required to go down that trail inexorably increase. There is nothing that human ingenuity can do to change that inexorable law. It is not surprising, therefore, that despite the growth in the economy the real costs of getting resources are increasing faster than the economy is growing. In fact, that is the fundamental reason why we are unable to afford the clean-up of the environment which is caused by our rapacious use of resources.

We have serious concerns about the general philosophy that lies behind this idea that we can now go offshore into the ocean and exploit the resources of the ocean. There are limits to how far we can do it and those limits are not fully recognised by government or opposition. That is the genesis of wanting to go into this newer and less exploited environment to exploit resources which we can no longer find on the land in adequate quantities.

Having said that, I point out that one of the conclusions that sort of argument leads one to is that it would be highly desirable to have an inventory of the resources available in Australia, not only to this generation but also to future generations. One of the things that has impeded the conservation movement in pushing that line for a long time has been that on land the possession of an exploration licence has automatically led to the right to exploit. If that obtains, one is very wary of exploring because it means that as soon as something is found the decision—which should be made very carefully—to exploit or to leave that resource for future generations cannot be made properly. It is made automatically in the light of the fact that there is an exploration licence and somebody has found something.

It is particularly pleasing, therefore, to find in this legislation that the various licences are to be separated and that a licence to explore does not automatically lead to a licence to exploit. That is certainly a step in the right direction. Moreover, one finds in this main bill that, if a person or persons have a right to explore and that licence does not automatically lead to a licence to mine, they are not necessarily entitled to any compensation. I want to explore that factor also in a little more detail in the committee stage because I do not think it is entirely clear what `property' means. The bill sidesteps the issue by simply pointing to the constitution. As we know from the recent High Court case, the constitution does not give complete clarity to the definition of `property'. Nonetheless, we see the fact that these licences are to be separated as a step in the right direction.

Given that, we are not averse to the idea of an intermediate licence, a retention licence, which lies between the right to explore and the right to exploit. We see no difficulty with allowing a company to hold a retention licence for a period of five years for various reasons—perhaps technical reasons relating to the inability to exploit that resource at that time, or related perhaps to the economic conditions or some other conditions—in the hope that at some limited time in the future the person or persons will then be able to exploit that resource.

We notice also that under subclause 43(1) and (2) the bill clearly recognises the question of native title. The granting of any of these licences does not supersede native title and native title is retained while these licences are in effect. No doubt, that will stir up the opposition as happened yesterday in relation to the wet tropics world heritage legislation. It is particularly pleasing to see that specifically mentioned in the bill and, of course, it is in conformity with the legislation that was passed late last year.

Returning to the question of the inventory for a moment, we have suggested an amendment because we do not think, contrary to what Senator Boswell just said, that clause 376 adequately deals with the matter. Clause 376 qualifies clause 27(1). Clause 27(2) has three conditions—(a), (b) and (c)—all of which are connected by an `and', not an `or'. Subclause 27(2)(b) reads:

SPEECH.PARA: the person gives the Designated Authority a report that relates not only to those blocks but also to other blocks;

In other words, that is a condition which has to be fulfilled before the information can be released. The clause also says that the information which is released that relates to those other blocks is not confidential information.

PARA.TAB: If this separation of the various sorts of licences is to fulfil the role we think it rightly should fulfil—allowing the establishment of a more comprehensive inventory of Australia's resources, not just for this generation but for future generations—clearly, at the time when the licences expire, that information should become public. That is the reason for that amendment. It is fundamental to the idea that over time we build up that sort of an inventory and we then more intelligently decide when it is that we will actually exploit a particular resource in the interests of this or later generations.

We are also somewhat concerned about the sorts of conditions which may be attached to licences. The bill describes the kinds of conditions that can be attached to each of the four licences provided for in the bill. The licence may—I stress may—include conditions requiring the licence holder to take out insurance; to lodge a security with the designated authority; to take steps to protect the environment of the licence area, including conditions relating to the protection of wildlife and minimising the effect on the environment of the licence area; and to repair any damage to the environment caused by the activities allowed for in the licence. It is our very strong view that these matters are so fundamental that these conditions should not be the prerogative of the designated authority to determine whether they are attached. These conditions should and must be attached to protect the environment.

Having said that, I emphasise that even though a condition is attached, that is not to say that, if a mining company is not doing the right thing, the condition which is attached may necessarily be a particularly arduous one. But it does mean that with every licence given attention will be drawn to the need to protect the environment. Conditions will attach which will lead to the taking out of insurance and the repair of any damage to the environment. We feel that is quite reasonable and in conformity with the rest of the bill. I foreshadow a Democrat amendment to make such conditions mandatory.

Other amendments deal with the issue of exploration and mining in marine parks and reserves. As honourable senators are no doubt aware, the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act 1975 proscribes the recovery of minerals in wilderness zones. The recovery of minerals is defined in the act as including prospecting, exploration and mining activities. The act also proscribes the recovery of minerals in a park or reserve other than where the operations are carried out in accordance with the plan of management relating to the park or reserve.

The Democrats are opposed to any exploration or mining activity inside protected parks and reserves. That is an absolute that we have held for a very long time. Exploration inside parks only creates commercial pressure to excise areas from national parks. We have seen the very considerable debate that went on in relation to the Kakadu National Park over many years with the initial declaration of Kakadu excluding certain areas and the subsequent inclusion in stage 3 of Coronation Hill and surrounding parts over which there were certain mining licences. But our belief is that mining is a totally inappropriate land use in these protected areas.

There are legislative examples where certain parks or reserves are protected from mining activity. I have mentioned already the Kakadu National Park as one such example. It is specifically protected under 10(1A) of the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act 1975, which states:

SPEECH.PARA: No operations for the recovery of minerals shall be carried on in Kakadu National Park.

The Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act 1975 also specifically excludes mining activity in the park. Section 38 of the act states that no operations for the recovery of minerals shall be carried out in the marine park other than for the purpose of research and investigations relevant to the establishment, care and development of the marine park or for scientific research.

PARA.TAB: Australia has four marine parks in Commonwealth areas. In each case the management plan excludes mining activity. But that does not mean in future necessarily that mining will be excluded in any further parks which are established. We believe that an amendment which excludes mining in marine national parks is necessary.

Given that the precedent of no mining in marine national parks has now been set four times, it is time for the Commonwealth legislation to recognise that mining inside protected marine parks is an inappropriate activity. A legislative recognition prohibiting exploration of mining in national parks would provide a clear signal to the mining industry that parks exist to protect the environment and for the enjoyment of all future generations, not for commercial extractive uses. I see that time is running out, so—

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you want to incorporate it?
—No. I will leave for committee stage a couple of other points and questions that I wish to raise with the minister in the interpretation of particular parts of the bill.

—The Greens (WA) heard that the states and the various state departments of minerals and energy were very happy with the Offshore Minerals Bill. That is always a worry—especially considering the current level of environmental understanding that has been exhibited by a number of states, including my state. So we start with the same kinds of concerns that have been mentioned by Senator Coulter.

PARA.TAB: At the outset it is important to place on record the Green concern that this bill has not been referred to a Senate committee. The main bill in particular is a major piece of legislation with 440 clauses, plus schedules. Whilst I am aware that a substantial consultation process took place with both the offshore exploration industry and the state governments, I would point out that the bill's content is of major importance, as it provides the framework for offshore minerals exploration in this country and deserves serious consideration in the parliament through the Senate committee process.

In the limited time available to review this bill, however, we have some concerns relating to the environmental implications of the offshore mineral exploration that is the subject of this bill. This form of mineral exploration has potentially devastating implications for the environments in which they operate. Due to the fact that this work is carried out in marine environments, there are some unique ecological problems. In coastal areas, for example, the nature of the seabed can result in major siltation problems if any disturbance occurs as a result of exploration or mineral mining activity. Seagrass beds and reefs are good examples of marine ecosystems that could suffer devastating consequences of siltation.

It should be noted in this regard that concerns about the ecological wellbeing of reefs, sea grasses and other marine ecosystems are not the preserve of radical greenies and conservationists. The economic wellbeing of the fishing and tourism industries, for example, are totally reliant on the continued health of these natural systems. The fishing industry in some areas would be wiped out. The reefs and sea grasses that act as nursery areas for young fish and crustaceans were destroyed by the activities of the offshore mineral industry. Given the enormous contribution of fishing and tourism to the regional economies in many areas of Australia, this could be disastrous for the entire economy of a town or region.

Although I am pleased to see that the bill contains references to the need for the licence holder `to take steps to protect the environment of the licence area', this is not a mandatory condition to the exploration, retention, mining or works licences. As the bill currently stands, a joint authority may grant a licence on whatever conditions it deems, and these conditions may include certain environmental conditions.

As we have heard from Senator Coulter, the Democrats will be proposing a series of amendments that will amend the requirement for environmental conditions to make them mandatory. The Greens wholeheartedly support these amendments and trust that the government will match with some positive action its rhetoric from earlier in the week about its wonderful environmental record, and that also it will support these amendments.

It is recognised that there are some mining activities, especially in offshore areas, which will not have significant environmental impacts. Having a mandatory clause does not affect that. We could easily, by requirements, simply write `No special conditions required'. At least the government has made a requirement that each kind of mining activity is dealt with or somebody has had the role of checking whether or not special environmental conditions apply in that case. To not have it or have it on an ad hoc basis seems to be a very dangerous precedent if the government is attempting to engage in a situation where there is a degree of certainty—whether it is for the mining industry, conservationists, or other industries that are dependent on the environment for their livelihood.

The Greens have an additional concern on this bill in the need to protect areas of high conservation value. This nation is situated on the smallest continent on the planet, with a vast coastline that contains some of the most unique marine ecosystems in the world. The Great Barrier Reef is obviously one of the better of these systems. There are many other areas, such as the Ningaloo reef in the north-west of Western Australia, that have been established as marine parks or marine reserves. These areas require an absolute guarantee of protection.

One of the special things about the Ningaloo marine park is that it is considered perhaps second only in significance to the Great Barrier Reef but, most importantly, is less damaged in many ways than the barrier reef. In fact, it is even more important in some ways as an example of a pristine ecosystem. It is something that we do not value enough in Australia because it probably makes it one of the second most important coastal reefs in the world.

I am pleased, therefore, to see that the Democrats have proposed some amendments to this bill that incorporate a prohibition on offshore exploration or mining activity. The Greens fully support these amendments and trust that the government and opposition will also support this obvious and natural desire to ensure protection of areas of high conservation value. If we are going to allow mining activity in any form in national parks or reserves, as is done in Western Australia, then we may as well eliminate the concept altogether.

Finally, I would like to refer briefly to clause 43, which relates to native title rights. I will be seeking an explanation from the minister during the committee stage of the intent of this clause, but I would like to place on record the Greens' commitment to ensuring that Aboriginal people have the right to participate in negotiations with respect to any licence applying to an area where native title rights may exist. I trust that the government is also committed in this regard. Nevertheless, the Greens will be supporting the legislation per se, despite the concerns I have outlined today.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —The comments of Senator Margetts and Senator Coulter followed a similar theme. We will not be supporting the amendments that Senator Coulter has indicated that he will be moving.

PARA.TAB: The bills we have before us—the Offshore Minerals Bill, the Offshore Minerals (Consequential Provisions) Bill and the Offshore Minerals (Retention Licence Fees) Bill—were prepared after very lengthy consultations with the states and the Northern Territory. I understand both the substance and the style of the bills will provide a model for complementary state legislation. In fact, they are based on previous legislation that has been in existence for almost 10 years.

SPEECH.PARA: The enactment of the state legislation in due course will provide a common mining code for offshore minerals right around Australia.

PARA.TAB: The bill does not introduce any major changes in policy, but provides streamlined and improved procedures for the administration of offshore mining of minerals. Senator Boswell referred to plain English, which is appreciated by anyone attempting to read legislation. The legislation will serve well the growing interest in offshore minerals exploration and production. Many of the improved procedures have been suggested by the states, which administer the legislation on behalf of the Commonwealth and which have the practical experience of administering mining legislation.

In respect to a number of specific matters that have been raised, generally Senator Coulter's suggested amendments on marine parks will not be accepted. They run counter to existing policies expressed in the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act. Indeed, they run counter to policies adopted by both the Commonwealth and state governments in the COAG meetings in terms of the multiple land use principles embodied in the ESD strategy.

The National Parks Act does not have a flat prohibition on mining in national parks. However, wildernesses are free from mining. The act allows for management plans for national parks to proscribe mining if the nature of the area dictates it. To date no mining has been allowed under management plans in national parks.

In respect of the reference made to clause 118, the environmental conditions are locality specific and depend upon, firstly, the nature of the activities that are proposed and, secondly, the environmental sensitivity of the area. The Commonwealth minister, a member of the joint authority, has the final say on any of those conditions. All decisions of the Commonwealth are subject to the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974, and conditions will be framed after consultation with the Commonwealth Environmental Protection Agency. The environmental regulations will be developed as experience is gained in offshore minerals activity. Regulations will apply equally to all areas.

Clause 376 provides that reports are publicly available after the licence or successor licence expires. This ensures that all geological, environmental and other information is publicly available. Licence holders are required to put in regular reports which are held by the states and the Commonwealth geological organisations. The requirement to publish would be very costly as reports can be numerous and voluminous. The register is publicly available and people can find out when licences expire. Those are some comments that I want to make at this stage in response to the issues raised by Senator Coulter. He will obviously be raising some other matters in the committee stages.

TALK.START.PARA: —We move on now to my first amendment. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1)Clause 27, page 19, line 4, paragraph (1)(a), after "Designated Authority" insert: "and the licence has not expired, or is a successor licence to the licence".

As I was explaining earlier in the second reading stage of this debate, it seems to me that one enormous potential advantage of this legislation which moves us forward from earlier mining legislation—at this stage it is only a potential advantage—is the ability to establish a resource inventory for Australia. But that depends upon the information becoming available once the exploration is over—if in fact that is not followed by a retention licence or a licence to mine. If exploration has been carried out and any licensing over that particular block lapses, it seems to me that that information should come back into the public domain. That is the way that we would progressively establish an inventory.

PARA.TAB: When I raised this matter with some of the advisers, they said, `Look at section 376'. I looked at that proposed section, but it is only part of clause 27(2). The three paragraphs of clause 27(2) are connected by the word `and'. In other words, every single paragraph has to be fulfilled before information can be released. Clause 27(1) states that information given by a licence holder to the designated authority is confidential information. Clause 27(2) states:
(2) However, if:
(a)a person is required to give the Designated Authority a report in relation to particular blocks; and—

SPEECH.PARA: I stress the word `and'—

PARA.TAB: (b)the person gives the Designated Authority a report that relates not only to those blocks but also to other blocks; and—

SPEECH.PARA: and those words are important: to other blocks—

PARA.TAB: (c)the Designated Authority is required to make the report available under section 376.

SPEECH.PARA: That is where that proposed section comes in. It continues:
the information that relates to those other blocks is not confidential information.

In other words, there is a very strict limitation on the release of information. Whilst that is absolutely understandable in the context of confidentiality while a licence is in place, what I am seeking to do with this amendment, by amending (1)(a), is to say that once all of the licences—that is, exploration, retention and mining licences—have lapsed, then that information should become available. What I am attempting to do is to qualify proposed section 27(1)(a) so that after `designated authority' we insert the words `and the licence has not expired, or is a successor licence to the licence'. In other words, if a licence is still current, the information remains confidential, which is reasonable. But once those licences have lapsed, it seems to me in the public interest that information should become public information.

PARA.TAB: That is not to say, as the parliamentary secretary tried to imply a few moments ago, that necessarily the department, the designated authority or whatever, has to go out and expensively publish that information. All it says is that the information is no longer confidential. If it is applied for, one can get access to that information. It may be for any reason. It may be that other people want to mine or explore. At least they are not duplicating an effort that has already been made, increasing the total expenditure on the community, by exploring for something which has already been properly explored. There may be other reasons. Other attributes of the block may need to be looked at, and at least it becomes a database.

I am aware that in South Australia—and this may be true in other states—the Department of Mines and Energy carries out very extensive exploration, and that information is in the public domain. Those who want to exploit very often use that information as the base on which they then carry out further exploration. They get an enormous benefit from publicly funded exploration work.

All this is attempting to do is to ensure that, when they have carried out their exploration and they no longer want to proceed with anything else, once the licence ceases, whatever information they have obtained is no longer confidential. It comes back into the public domain and becomes part of the public information base that can be used by other people. That seems to me to be not only reasonable but highly desirable in view of the commitment which this government has stated as to sustainability. In other words, one of the necessary bases for sustainability is establishing an inventory of the resources available, not only to this generation but to the next.

This amendment is very simple. I am surprised that even though the parliamentary secretary expressed the view that this bill comes at the end of a considerable period of negotiation with state and territory governments, nonetheless, this amendment is not acceptable. I would strongly urge the parliamentary secretary to reconsider and accept this amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last week a great Western Australian died—Daisy Utemorrah of Utemorrah country. Her name is probably better known in Western Australia than was the name of Eddie Mabo in the Murray Islands. Like Eddie Mabo she did not live long enough to achieve her dream of having her native land returned to her people. But the dream will continue in her name.

PARA.TAB: However, I will not get involved in whether her claim will or should be upheld. It will never come to a conclusion so far as I can see. Honourable senators may ask why it will not come to a conclusion. I wish to place on record my views as to why it will not come to a conclusion. It will not come to a conclusion because of ATSIC and the way it has been performing in Western Australia. In Western Australia, and in other places, ATSIC has been playing favourites—as has this government. For a long time there has been a bone of contention. There was supposed to be an inquiry.

In 1983 the Kamali people of which Daisy Utemorrah was a member broke away from the Kimberley Land Council because their interests were not being catered for. Since then they have attempted to be heard by governments, ministers, the former Department of Aboriginal Affairs and now ATSIC.

When the Senate committee ran around Australia on that fast and furious trip before the native title legislation, hardly any organisations knew what it was on about. Perhaps there was a reason for that. This government rushed that inquiry so as to be able to then rush the native title legislation through this Senate. Probably the committee had no time to let everyone who was interested know so they could appear before it. The government, in its ever growing haste to get this legislation through parliament before Christmas, was, of course, aided and abetted by the Greens and the Australian Democrats.

The problem started in Queensland. Honourable senators will remember that the jaunt around Australia by the committee started in Brisbane. I would like to quote very briefly from the Hansard report of the sitting in Brisbane. Perhaps even my colleagues might listen to this. Mr Wharton was asked by the chairman who he was representing. He replied:

SPEECH.PARA: You asked me to represent myself and state who I represent. It is a pity that people did not ask the magnificent seven when they were down in Canberra who they represented and who they were supposed to speak for. It is a shame that it comes around now, when I am getting asked who I represent.
He let the committee know that the people who went to Canberra at the time did not represent all the Aboriginal communities of Queensland.

PARA.TAB: The position is the same with the Kamali group in Western Australia. The Kamali people were not told that the committee would be in Western Australia, and they were not invited to make a submission. After all, they have been divorced from the Kimberley Land Council for at least 10 years. That Kimberley Land Council, which does not speak for the Kamali group, had enough money to send four people to Perth to be heard by the committee.

As the Kamali group does not accept the KLC as its representative, it should have been given the opportunity to be heard but it was not allowed to do so. The same sort of thing occurred in Queensland. This committee, as it did in Queensland, only listened to a small group.

In the past the Kamali group has been very ably represented by a Rosemary O'Grady. The whole community has been starved of finance to fight its case. In October 1993 the local ATSIC in Derby approved funds for the ongoing fight to get equity. The approval was sent to Canberra but did not arrive here. I have the government gazette and I will quote that on another occasion.

The land title claim that the Kamali group are fighting for in Western Australia is a pre-native title claim—pre-native title in Western Australia and pre-native title that the federal government rammed through this parliament before Christmas. The group is continuing its action in the Supreme Court of Western Australia without any finance whatsoever.

To put the situation in perspective, the Kamali people represent 2,000 Aborigines in the Kimberley and the Kimberley Land Council represents 2,000 only. If the Kamali group represented no more than 100 people and the rest of the 4,000 backed the Kimberley Land Council, I would not question the council's motives. But when we have the Kamali group representing 2,000 people—in other words, half the number of the people in the area—I believe it should be listened to. Indeed, it has not been listened to for the past 10 years. No matter where they turn to try to get equity to keep this land claim going before the Supreme Court of Western Australia, they are told that there is nothing whatsoever available.

Yesterday I talked to people in the Kamali office in Western Australia and I asked them to fax me some material on their claims for finance. They told me that they are so starved of finance that they did not even have a fax machine. That is how bad it is. Whatever the outcome of that Utemorrah land claim, it will have to go through the courts to be sorted out. I am not going to prejudge whether the claim is right or what the result of the claim will be. But I believe that the Kamali people have certainly got a case that must be heard by the Supreme Court of Western Australia, the court which at present they are locked into.

I call upon the minister to find out why they are being starved of funds and I ask him to put the situation right. As Senator Bell would know, I have been attempting to get an inquiry into the workings of ATSIC to make sure that everyone gets access and equity. I intend to move later this year for an inquiry which can determine why people are not being treated equally. The Kamali group tell me that this has been going on for quite a few years. Just like the Kalgoorlie people, the Kamalis are not getting their fair share of equity. I call upon the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, Mr Tickner, and the Senate to take note of what I have said and to see that justice is done in this case.
