PARA.TAB: In a democracy it is important that ministers of the crown and bureaucracies respond to concerns and complaints from the community. In my view there can hardly be a more legitimate complaint than in relation to tobacco advertising. Senator Richardson has had photographs and other detailed information. He has had three letters. Why is it not possible for him to answer? Is it that he does not want to upset any mates in the tobacco industry? In my view, his inaction is a violation of his mandate to uphold the law.

The second issue that I raise relates to exemptions that the Minister for Health can specify for tobacco advertising associated with international events. On 15 September 1993, in the government Gazette, the minister gave an exemption for the Adelaide Grand Prix. That grand prix was held in the first week in November 1993, but the exemption from the prohibition on advertising lasts until 14 September 1994. In other words, in September 1994, cigarette companies could claim to be still advertising their product under the guise of promoting the November 1993 Adelaide Grand Prix.

I suggest that is a nonsense, outrageous and a con trick on the Australian community and Australia's young. I cannot agree in principle with any exemptions to the ban. But if we must have exemptions, then surely the exemptions should be for the promotion of a sporting or cultural event. It should not be a Clayton's exemption that allows promotion after the event. Looking at the semantics, I wonder whether it could be a promotion after an event. Should it not perhaps be a demotion? What is the term for continued publicising of an event which has already occurred? It certainly should not be promotion. Surely on the grounds of common sense the exemption should end a day or two after the event.

There is no other option but to call on the minister to abide by the spirit of the Tobacco Advertising Prohibition Act and limit the length of time for exemptions under the act to a day or two after the event itself, leaving practical time to remove any promotional material. Failure to abide by the spirit of the act means that the minister is undermining the act, the work of his own health department and health departments around Australia by not encouraging a lowering of the incidence of tobacco consumption in our community.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 17 August 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) What consultations were conducted, and with which community groups, leading to the appointment of Mr Don Burke as sole Community Representative on the Board of the National Registration Authority for Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals.
(2) Why were people with credibility to community groups not approached, consulted or chosen.
(3) What restrictions are placed on the Community Representative on the board of the National Registration Authority from disclosing information.
(4) If there are any restrictions, why do they exist and under what circumstances do they apply.
(5) Are community groups or individuals to be charged $150 to be on the mailing list of the National Registration Authority, if so why.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) & (2) I am advised that all main community organisations, public interest groups and environment organisations were consulted on the composition of the Board. Professor Selinger was the preferred nominee of most of consumer groups. He is, of course, the Chairperson of the Board. Mr Don Burke is well acquainted with agricultural chemicals particularly as they relate to the home and garden market and the concerns of consumers.

Under the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals (Administration) Act 1992 Directors are not appointed as representatives of any particular group, but in making appointments the Minister must ensure that collectively Directors have experience in the regulation of chemical products under the law of a State or Territory; the agricultural and veterinary chemicals industry; the protection of the interests of consumers; primary production and occupational health and safety.

(3) & (4) The Government is committed to open and transparent processes as part of the National Registration Authority's operations. To this end, summarised information will be available to the public before decisions are made. Public Release Summaries are issued containing information about a product's toxicology, residue profile, environmental fate, and other relevant considerations such as occupational health and safety. A consultation program has also been put in place for products containing new active constituents whereby public input is sought before making a determination on the registration of such products.
However, under the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Act 1988, as amended, information which is commercially confidential can not be disclosed. All Directors are bound by this provision.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 20 December 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) Will 50 megalitres of water a day be returned back into the Snowy River in place of the 7 megalitres per day; if not, why not.

(2) Will the Minister agree to return 25 per cent of the original 3 200 megalitres per day (800 megalitres) back into the river as a long-term goal; if so, by what date will 25 per cent of the water be returned; if not, why not.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) Releases of water from Lake Jindabyne at a rate of up to 50 megalitres per day will continue to be made in order to meet the riparian requirements prescribed by the Department of Water Resources for the Snowy River within New South Wales. These riparian requirements are flow rates within the river channel at selected sites and not "from Lake Jindabyne", so that releases can be as low as 7 megalitres per day during wetter periods and up to 50 megalitres per day during dry periods.

(2) The return of 25 per cent of the original 3 200 megalitres per day (800 megalitres per day) back into the river is not at the discretion of the Minister. The matter is subject to the Agreement between the States of New South Wales and Victoria and the Commonwealth Government and as such the timing of changes to the release rates are dependent on developments between the States and Commonwealth and to State sharing arrangements of water from the Snowy River.

Increased releases to the Snowy River would be complementary to reduced flows for irrigation, the environment and salinity control along the Lower Murray River. In energy terms alone, the 800 megalitres per day represents 320 000 megawatt hours per annum of electricity with an annual market value of $20 million.
